Sume calamentum, et hyssopum, et origanum, et rutam, et sseah, et chamomillam, et abrotanum, et similia eis ex herbis: et aggrega ea omnia, aut quaedam eorum in olla, et submergantur cum aceto, et bulliant: et olla sit lutata cum luto decenter: et sit in medio ollae foramen, super quod componatur instrumentum concauum secundum hunc modum.	Sumac, and hyssop, and oregano, and rut, and myrrh, and chamomile, and abrotanum, and similar plants from herbs; and all of them be gathered together, or some of them in a pot, and immersed with vinegar and boiled: and the whole be stirred with a decanter: and there be left an opening in the middle of the vessel, above which an instrument be placed according to this mode.
Fiat ex argento, aut aere: et intromittatur extremitas, in qua est granatum, in os infirmi, donec ascendat uapor ad uuulam super cannulam, donec obscuretur uuula multum.	Let it be made of silver or brass; and the end, in which is the graver, be inserted into the opening of the tube to the nose, until the steam ascends to the eye-lid, and much darkness ensue.
Deinde itera super ipsam multotiens, donec arescat.	Then let it be frequently moved over it, until it is thoroughly dried.
Et caue, ne facias hanc curationem in principio aduentus apostematis.	And beware: do not perform this cure at the first approach of apoplexy.
Plaerumque enim addit in apostemate: et non oportet ut facias illud nisi apud declinationem apostematis eius calidi.	Indeed, for this adds to apoplexy; and thou shouldst not perform it unless at the decline of apoplexy from heat.
Si autem non est praesens tibi hoc instrumentum, tunc accipe cannam, et compone in extremitate eius corticem oui: ut non comburatur os infirmi: quoniam cortex oui prohibet uaporem comburere os: et haec est ex bona curatione cum salute.	But if you do not have this instrument with you, then take a tube, and fit a stopcock to the end of it, so that it may not burn the nose; for the bark prevents the steam from burning the nose; and this is good curing with health.
¶ De extractione spinarum, et ossium de gula.	As to the extraction of spines and bones from the throat.
Caput XXXVIII.	Chapter XXXIX.
Multotiens adhaeret in gutture os, aut spina piscis, aut aliud.	Often a bone or spine adheres in the throat, or a fish-spine, or something else.
Oportet ergo ut extrahas quod ex eis est apparens super quod cadit uisus, postquam premis linguam cum instrumento apud solem, et declaratur tibi quod est in gutture.	Then thou shouldst draw forth what appears thereon, which is the object that causes the difficulty, when you press the tongue with an instrument against the light and show it to thyself; because it will be seen on the tongue.
Et quod non apparet tibi et occultatur in gutture, oportet ut facias uomere infirmum antequam digeratur cibus in stomacho.	And that which is not manifest to thee and is hidden in the throat, thou shouldst make a sick person fast before any food is digested in the stomach.
Fortasse enim egredietur res annexa per uomitum.	Forsooth, what attached may go forth through the sweat.
Aut deglutiat infirmus frustum napi, aut radicem lactucae, aut deglutiat buccellam panis sicci: aut accipiat frustum spongiae marinae siccae lenis: et liga ipsum in filo, deinde deglutiat ipsum.	Or the sick man shall swallow a straw of wheat, or a leaf of lettuce, or he shall swallow a dry cracker; or he shall take a dry sea-sponge, and tie it with a string, then shall swallow it: and bind also that which he has taken in a string.
Cum ergo peruenit ad locum ubi sunt spinae, aut os, et extrahitur, tunc egreditur.	And so, when it has come to the place where there are bones, or a jaw, and is extracted, then he goes away.
Si ergo non egreditur cum eo quod diximus: tunc utere instrumento ex plumbo secundum hanc formam.	But if he does not go out with it as we have said: then use the instrument of lead in this form.
Sit grossius quam Radius parumper, et in extremitate eius sit curuitas, quam intromittat in guttur suum cum facilitate: et ipse habeat caput suum eleuatum sursum.	Let it be larger than the radius by a little, and at its end let there be a curve, which he can insert into his throat with ease: and let him hold his own head raised up.
Et caueat a tactu suae epiglotis, ut non accidat ei tussis, et impellat cum eo os, aut spinam, aut intromittat ipsum medicus manu sua.	And he should guard against touching his epiglottis, so that it does not cause him to cough, and drives out with it the bone, or the spine, or inserts it himself with his own hand.
Verum quod infirmus intromittat, hoc est melius: propter scientiam suam de loco rei annexae: et impellat inferius, aut trahat manum suam cum instrumento sursum, totum illud secundum quantitatem quae praeparatur ei, donec egrediatur.	But if the sick person inserts it, that is better: because of his knowledge about the part of the body concerned: and he pushes it down, or pulls up his hand with the instrument upwards, all this according to the quantity that has been prepared for him, until it comes out.
¶ De extractione Sanguisugae.	On the extraction of blood from the nose.
Caput XXXIX.	Chapter XXXIX On drawing blood from the nose.
Quando medicatur sanguisuga cum eo quod dixi in diuisione ex curatione cum medicinis, et non confert, tunc considera in gutture infirmi coram sole, siue apud solem postquam premis linguam eius cum instrumento quod narraui tibi.	When you are treating with medicines and the blood does not come out, then consider the throat in front of the sun, or behind it, after you have touched your tongue with the instrument that I have told you about.
Si ergo cadit uisus tuus super sanguisugam, extrahe eam cum uncino paruo, aut cum gesti subtilibus decenter.	But if your yawn falls on the leech, then extract it with a small hook, or with subtle gestures.
Quod si non est possibile cum eis: tunc accipe cannulam concauam, et intromitte eam in guttur infirmi usque prope guttur: deinde intromitte in concauitatem cannulae ferrum ignitum cum igne.	That if it is not possible with them: then take a narrow tube and insert it into the throat as far as the throat: and then insert into the tube an iron that has been heated red hot with fire.
Fac illud multotiens: et abstineat infirmus ab aqua tota die.	Make it do this many times: and let the sick person refrain from drinking water all day.
Deinde accipiat uitreatam plenam aqua frigida, et aperiat os eius in ea: et colluat os suum cum ea, et non deglutiat ex ea aliquid: et moueat aquam una hora post aliam cum manu sua.	Then let him take a full cup of cold water, and open his mouth there: and let him put his mouth on it, and let him not swallow anything from it: and let him move his hand with the water.
Sanguisuga enim ilico cum sentit aquam cadit.	For the leech immediately falls when it feels the water.
Si autem non egreditur cum eo quod narrauimus, tunc suffumiga infirmum cum cimicibus, aut cum asa cum instrumento quod narraui in suffumigatione uuulae.	But if it does not go out with him that we have described, then suffumigate the sick with herbs, or with a tube as an instrument that we have described in the suffumigation of the uula.
Fac illud multotiens, quoniam ipsa cadet.	Do this many times, because it will decrease on its own.
Et modus operationis in suffumigatione est, ut accipias ollam, in qua sint prunae uiuae cum igne: et olla sit cooperta cum coopertorio, in cuius medio sit foramen: et componatur in illo foramine extremitas instrumenti.	And the method of operation in suffumigation is, so that you take an olla in which there are prunes with fire: and the olla be covered with a cover, in which there is a hole: and the end of the instrument be placed in that hole.
Deinde proiice suffumigationem, et ponat infirmus os suum in extremitate cannulae, et claudat os suum, ut non egrediatur suffumigatio, donec scias quod suffumigatio iam peruenit ad sanguisugam.	Then throw the suffumigation and let the sick put his mouth at the end of the cannula, and close his mouth, so that the suffumigation does not go out, until you know that the suffumigation has reached the blood-vessel.
Nam sanguisuga statim cadet.	For the sucking-in will cease immediately.
Quod si non cadit, tunc itera suffumigationem multotiens.	If it does not cease, then repeat the suffumigation many times.
Et toleret infirmus sitim, et comedat salsa, et allia, et non bibat aquam.	And let the sick suffer thirst, and eat salt and other things, and do not drink water.
Necesse est ergo ut egrediatur cum hoc regimine.	Therefore it is necessary that he go out with this regimen.
Et haec est forma instrumenti cum quo extrahitur sanguisuga ex gutture, quando cadit super ipsam uisus.	And this is the form of the instrument from which the sucking-in is taken from the throat when it falls on top of the uisus.
Est simile forcipibus, sicut uides: nisi quia est ei haee curuitas quae intromittitur ad guttur.	It is similar to pincers, as you see: unless because of its slenderness it enters into the throat.
Et extremitas eius similis ori auis quae nominatur ciconia, in quo est asperitas limae: quando comprehendit aliquid, non dimittit ipsum omnino.	And the end of it is similar to an ear, which is called a cicogna, in which there is a sharpness of the point: and when it embraces anything, does not let go at all.
¶ De apertione Apostematum, et eorum sectione, et cura in genere.	Regarding the opening of the aphemates, and their division, and care in general.
Caput XL.	Chapter 40.
Apostematum species sunt multae, multorum modorum, secundum quod uenit rememoratio eorum, scilicet unius, et unius in hoc libro: et sunt diuersae in perforatione eorum, et sectione ipsorum ex duobus modis.	There are many species of aphemates, and many ways of remembering them, namely one, and one in this book: and they differ in the perforation of them, and in the division of themselves into two kinds.
Quorum unus est ex specie apostematis in seipso, et eo quod comprehendit ex humiditatibus.	Of which one is a species of aphemate in itself, and on account of its encompassing moist things.
Et modus secundus est propter loca, in quibus accidit ex corpore.	And a second method is because of the places where it occurs from the body.
Quoniam apostema accidens in capite, est aliud ab apostemate accidente in ano: et apostema accidens in loco carnoso, est aliud ab apostemate accidente in iuncturis: et unicuique eorum est iudicium suum ex operatione.	Since the apoplexy occurs in the head, it is different from the apoplexy that occurs in the anus; and since the apoplexy occurs in a soft place, it is different from the apoplexy that occurs at the joints; and each of them has its own judgment based on the operation.
Et ex apostematibus sunt quae non oportet ut perforentur, nisi post maturationem saniei in eis, et complementum eius: et ex eis sunt, quae oportet ut perforentur, dum sunt cruda, et non maturantur secundum complementum.	And of the apoplexies there are some that do not need to be pierced unless they have been maturated with blood and its complement; and of them are those that need to be pierced when they are raw and do not mature according to the complement.
Sicut apostemata quae sunt propinqua iuncturis.	As for the apoplexies that are near joints.
Quoniam apostema quando accidit prope iuncturam, et prolongatur esse eius, donec putrefit quod est in circumitu eius fortasse corrumpuntur ligamenta, aut nerui illius iuncturae: quare est caussa propior contractionis illius membri.	Since the apoplexy occurs when it is near a joint and is prolonged until what is in its surroundings may have been putrefied, perhaps the ligaments or the nerves of that joint are corroded; so this is the cause of the closer contraction of that member.
Aut est apostema apud membrum principale: quoniam si tu tardas perforationem eius, donec maturetur, nocebit uel illi, uel per illud membro principali.	Or it is an apoplexy in a main limb; since if you delay piercing it until it has matured, it will damage or hurt it or the main limb through which it passes.
Aut est prope anum, perfora ergo ipsum immaturum: et non oportet, ut perfores, apostema crudum, non completae digestionis, nisi quod est prope anum, ut non putrefiat profundum, et longetur ad interiora ani, et fiat fistula, aut fiat in termino eius quod non sanatur.	Or it is near a limb, so pierce it when it is immature: and you do not need to pierce a crude apoplexy that has not been completely digested, unless it is near a limb, so that it does not putrefy deeply, and it extends toward the inner parts, and becomes a fistula, or forms a hole in its end which does not heal.
Oportet ut scias horam perforationis apostematis, quod maturatum est secundum complementum: et est apud sedationem doloris, recessionem febris, et diminutionem rubedinis, et pulsationis, et acuitatem capitis apostematis: et reliqua signa.	You need to know the time of piercing the apoplexy that has matured according to its complement; and it is during a sedative pain, a decrease in fever, a decrease in redness, a pulse beat, and an acuteness of head pain for the apoplexy; and the rest of the signs.
Et oportet, ut facias eandem perforationem in inferiori loco apostematis, et uehementioris eminentiae: et sit perforatio uadens in longitudine corporis, si apostemata sunt in partibus manuum et pedum, et locis lacertorum, et chordarum, et neruorum, et arteriarum, et ad ultimum in omnibus locis aequalibus, quibus non est reflexio.	And you need to make the same piercing in the lower place of the apoplexy, and it is more severe: and the piercing should be flowing along the length of the body, if the apoplexies are in the parts of the hands and feet, and in the places of the ligaments, and the strings, and the nerves, and the arteries, and up to the last in all equal places, where there is no reflection.
In illis autem quae reflectuntur, uade cum perforatione secundum illud membrum.	In illis autem quae reflectuntur, uade cum perforatione secundum illud membrum.
Quando uero apostema est in locis carnosis: tunc melius est ut dimittas perforationem eius, donec confirmetur eius digestio, sicut diximus secundum complementum.	When, however, the hematoma is in fatty places: then it is better that you should abandon the perforation of it, until its digestion is confirmed, as we have said according to the supplement.
Quoniam si tu perforas ipsum ante illud, prolongatur cursus uirus ex eo, et est multae sordis et sordiciei, et fortasse indurantur labia eius, et profunditas eius.	For if you perforate it before that, the course of the virus extends from it, and it is full of dirt and dirt, and perhaps it hardens its lips, and its depth.
Et quaedam apostemata perforantur secundum latitudinem corporis apud necessitatem: aut secundum illud quo indiget membrum.	And some hematomas are perforate according to the width of the body when necessary: or according to that by which the limb is in need.
Et oportet, ut administres in apostematibus paruis perforationem paruam, et in apostematibus magnis perforationem amplam: aut sectiones multas per similitudinem magnitudinis apostematis.	And it is necessary that you administer a small perforation in small hematomas and a wide perforation in large hematomas: or sections according to the similarity of the size of the hematoma.
Et sunt ex apostematibus, in quibus oportet ut concauetur cutis: et incidatur quando iam facta est sicut pannus, et facta est in termino, quod iam mortua est: sicut illud quod accidit in multis, ut dubelet, et bubonibus.	And there are hematomas from which the skin should be sutured: and it happens when it has already been done like a cloth, and it has reached the end, because it is already dead: such as that happened to many, as the itching, and boils.
Et ex eis sunt quae secantur sectione habente tres angulos.	And among them are those who separate by cutting with three angles.
Et ex eis est, ex quo inciditur sicut figura folii myrti.	And among them is that from which the cut appears like a fig leaf.
Sicut apostema inguinum.	As the hematoma of the groin.
Et ex eis sunt in quibus administratur sectio rotunda, et sectio lunaris: et similes eis ex sectionibus.	And among them are those in which a round section is administered, and a lunar section: and similar ones from sections.
Illud uero cui non est caput, sicut sunt apostemata lenia superficialia, oportet ut perfores ipsum perforatione superficiali, uel plana tantum.	That, however, to which there is no head, such as are the soft surface hematomas, it is necessary that you perforate it with a superficial perforation, or simply a flat one.
Et oportet, quando apostema est grossum, et iam collegit saniem multam, et perforas ipsum, ut non properes et extrahas pus totum in illa hora: imo extrahe ex ipso partem eius.	And it is necessary that, when the hematoma is large and has already gathered a lot of blood, you perforate it so that it does not go out and expel all the blood at once: but extract a part from it.
Deinde opila apostema usque ad diem alium.	Then bandage the hematoma until the next day.
Deinde extrahe quiddam ex pus iterum.	Then extract some of the puss again.
Fac illud multotiens secundum gradationem, donec egrediatur: praecipue si infirmus est debilis uirtutis, aut mulier praegnans, aut puer paruus, aur senex decrepitus: spiritus enim animalis ab animali multotiens resoluitur cum egressione saniei: et fortasse moritur infirmus, et tu non percipis.	Make it many times according to the progression, until it comes out: especially if the person is weak of power, or a woman who is pregnant, or a young boy, or an old man decrepitous: for the animal spirit resolves from the animal with the exit of the blood: and perhaps the sick one dies, and you do not perceive it.
Caue ergo hoc capitulum cautela magna.	Therefore cause great care in this chapter.
Et post perforationem tuam, qua ista perforas apostemata, oportet ut abstergas uulnus: et considera.	And after your piercing, from which you have made a hole, it is necessary that you should remove the grit: and consider.
Si ergo est uulnus apostematis paruum, aut est sectio plana, tunc administra licinia ex lino, aut coto antiquo.	But if there is small grit in the post-hole, or it is a flat cut, then administer linen paste from flax, or ancient cotton.
Et si est apostema magnum, et fissurae perforationis multae sunt, oportet tunc ut intromittas in omnem fissuram licinium, donec perueniant adinuicem.	And if there is a great post-hole, and many cracks have been made by the piercing, then you should introduce linen into all the cracks until they are completely closed up.
Et si in apostemate abscidisti partem cutis, aut in circumitu concauasti eam: tunc oportet ut impleas eam coto ueteri, aut sicut quando texitur pannus, aut raditur lanugine lini absque humiditate: et stringe ipsum usque ad tertium diem.	And if you have cut off a part of the skin in the post-hole, or have worn it around the edge: then you should fill it with ancient cotton, or as when the cloth is smooth, or is brushed with linen floc: and press it firmly until the third day.
Deinde proiice ipsum, et cura illud cum eo quod oportet ex unguento, donec sanetur.	Then throw it away, and take care of that with you which you need to use ointment, until it is healed.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis in hora tuae operationis, tunc administra aquam frigidam, et acetum, postquam imbibitur in eis pannus: et ponis ipsum super locum fluxus sanguinis multotiens.	But if a flow of blood should happen in the hour of your operation, then administer cold water and vinegar, after which a cloth is dipped in it: and lay it down often on the place where the blood flows.
Si autem perseuerat fluxus sanguinis, tunc oportet ut administres regimen, et curationem, et pulueres, quae narraui in locis multis huius nostri libri, et ex diuisione.	But if the blood flow persists, then you should administer a regimen and cure, and powders, which I have described in many places of this book, and from division.
Si autem est in tempore hyemis, et locus apostematis est multorum neruorum: tunc oportet ut infundas puluillos cum uino, et oleo calidis: et ponas eos super loca.	But if it is in the time of winter, and the post-hole is full of cold air: then you should fill it with wine and hot oil: and lay it down.
Et si fuerit in aestate, et loca sunt carnosa: tunc oportet ut ponas puluillos imbibitos in aqua, et oleo, aut eum uino et oleo, et totum illud frigidum.	And if it is in the summer, and the places are fleshy: then you should fill them with water, and oil, or with wine and oil, and all that cold thing.
Donec quando erit dies tertius, sicut diximus, tunc oportet ut soluas apostema, et abstergas ipsum, et administres in curatione eius quod ei conuenit, donec sanetur.	Until the third day, as we have said, then you should remove the post, and wipe it clean, and administer to it what is proper to its cure, until it is healed.
Hoc est ergo quod necessarium est ex cognitione curationis apostematum uniuersaliter.	This is therefore what is necessary to know from the treatment of post-holes in general.
Secundum semitam uero distinctionis, iam dixi de omni apostemate, qualiter est uia ad curationem eius capitulatim singulariter.	Accordingly, I have already spoken about all forms of apoplexy, and how they affect the brain specifically.
¶ De sectione apostematum quae accidunt in cute capitis.	§ On the sections of the apophelies that occur on the scalp of the head.
Caput XLI.	Head 31.
Accidunt in cute capitis apostemata parua, et sunt ex speciebus Nodorum, quos continent tunicae, quae sunt eis sacci: quasi ipsa sint hausolati gallinae.	Apophelies that occur on the scalp of the head are small, and they are of two kinds: nodules, which are surrounded by a sheath, resembling little birds' nests.
Et ipsorum species sunt multae.	And there are many species of them.
Ex eis sunt pingues: et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditatem similem limo: et ex eis quae continent humiditatem similem frisatis et pultibus: et eis similibus, et ex eis sunt, quae sunt lapidea dura.	Of these there are some that are small; and those that contain a sort of moisture similar to mud; and those that contain a sort of moisture similar to hair and scabs; and some that are like stones, and of the same kind are the hard ones.
Et in sectione omnium, et ipsorum extractione non est timor, dum apud ipsorum sectionem non facit contrarietatem arteria.	And in the sectioning of all of them, there is no fear of their extraction, provided that you do not make a contradiction in the arteries when you are sectioning them.
Et operatio in sectione eorum est, ut experiaris ea cum instrumento, cuius forma uenit post haec, quod nominatur Intromissum, donec scias quid contineat.	And the operation in their sectioning is such that you should try it with an instrument whose shape comes after these, which is called the Intromissum, until you know what it contains.
Nam si est illud quod continet humiditas, tunc seca ipsum sectione secundum longitudinem sectione superficiali: secundum hanc formam.	For if that is what contains moisture, then make the sectioning of it according to length in a lateral direction: in this way.
Et incipe cum sectione ex linea b. ad lineam, g. Cum ergo euacuatur humiditas, tunc excoria kistin quae continet illam humiditatem, et non dimittas ex ea aliquid penitus.	And begin with the sectioning from line B to line G. And when the moisture is emptied, then remove the skin that contains it, and do not leave anything of it inside.
Multotiens enim redit, si remanet ex ea aliquid.	For many times if you leave something of it, it will return.
Deinde submerge cotum in unguento aegyptio, si est praesens: et si non, in aqua et sale: et imple cum eo uulnus, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	Then immerse the cotton in Egyptian ointment if it is present, and if not, in water and salt; and fill it with oil, and leave it until the next day.
Ipsum enim corrodet quod remansit ex kisti.	For this will corrode whatever remains of the skin.
Deinde itera super ipsum cotum cum aegyptio secundo, et tertio, et si indiges illo, donec confidas quia non remanserit ex kisti aliquid, tunc enim cura uulnus cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then repeat the application of Egyptian ointment a second and third time, and if you find it tolerable, trust that nothing remains of the skin, then the care with the ointment is enough, until it heals over.
Quod si apostema continet nodum pinguem: tunc seca ipsum secundum hanc formam, sectione habente formam crucis: et proiice uncinos inter duolabia sectionis, et excoria ipsum ab omni parte: et conare uirtutem tuam in extractione tunicae quae continet ipsum.	For if the apoplexy contains a round nodule, then make it dry according to this form, having a cross-shaped section; and throw the hooks between the two sections, and scrape off the skin entirely: and put your skill into practice when you extract the sheath that contains the nodule.
Si autem contrarietatem facit tibi arteria, tunc fac illud quod narrabo tibi post.	But if the artery causes you discomfort, then do what I will tell you after.
Et similiter fac in apostemate, si est lapideum, ex sectione, et curatione eadem, secundum quod diximus.	And also do the same in an apoplexy, if it is a stone, from the section, and the cure the same, as we have said.
Et sectio super apostema lapideum est facilior: quoniam est pauci sanguinis et humiditatis.	And the section over an apoplexy of a stone is easier: for there is little blood and moisture.
Et quandoque sunt quaedam horum apostematum quae sunt in capite in quibusdam hominibus, cum quibus penitus non est humiditas.	And sometimes some of these apoplexies which are in the head in certain men, in whom there is no moisture within.
Quod est: quia ego secui super apostema in capite mulieris uetulae, et inueni apostema sicut lapis solidus et durus, asper, albus, qui non poterat frangi: et si percuteretur cum eo aliquis proiiciendo, uulnerat ipsum.	That is: for I followed over an apoplexy in the head of a young woman, and I found an apoplexy like a solid stone and hard, rough, white, which could not be broken: and if anyone struck it with a blow, he wounded himself.
In aliis uero apostematibus accidentibus in capite, praeter haec scilicet apostemata quae accidunt in capitibus puerorum, et apud radices aurium, sectio eorum omnium sit sectio superficialis.	In others, however, of the accidents of apoplexies in the head, except those apoplexies which happen in the heads of boys, and at the roots of the ears, all of them are superficial sections.
Vel pone perforationem eorum semper ab inferiori parte eorum, ut alleuietur cursus saniei ad inferiora.	Or put a hole in them always from their lower part, that the course of blood may be directed towards the lower side.
Deinde cura ea cum eo quod conuenit eis ex curatione.	Then take care of them with that which is suitable to them from the cure.
¶ De sectione Strophularum in collo.	Regarding the section of the strophuli in the neck.
Caput XLII.	Chapter XXIV.
Multotiens acccidunt ista apostemata in collo, et sub assellis, et inguinibus: et quandoque accidunt in reliquo corpore.	These apoplexies often happen in the neck, and under the armpits, and in the groin: and sometimes they happen in the whole body.
Et super illa quae ex eis accidunt in collo, sunt unum, et multa: et generantur ab inuicem: et omnis Strophula ex eis est intra tunicam propriam ei, sicut est in nodis et apostematibus capitis, sicut narrauimus.	And over those which happen from them in the neck, there is one general one and many: and they are generated from a single source; and every strophula from them is within its own tunic, as we have said.
Et species harum Strophularum sunt multae.	And the kinds of these strophuli are many.
Et ex eis enim sunt lapideae: et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditates: et ex eis sunt malignae, quae non obediunt curationi.	For from them there are blisters: and from them there are those which contain moisture: and from them there are the evil ones, which do not submit to the cure.
In illa ergo quam ex eis uides bonae dispositionis in tactu, cuius manifestum est propinquum colori cutis, et mouetur ad omnem partem, et non est annexa cum neruis colli, neque cum guidegi, neque cum arteria, neque est profunda: oportet ut seces eam sectione superficiali a superiori parte ad inferiorem partem corporis ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. et excoria eam ab omni parte: et extende duo labia cutis cum uncino, aut cum uncinis multis, si indiges illo, sicut diximus in apostematibus capitis, et extrahe eam paulatim.	In that which you see from them a good disposition when touched, whose manifest is its close nearness to the color of the skin, and it moves to all parts, and it is not joined to the nerves of the neck, nor to the guide-fibers, nor to any artery, nor is it deep: let it be separated from that superficial section from the upper part towards the lower part of the body along a line, b. up to the line, g. and scrape it off from all parts: and extend two skin-lips with a hook, or with many hooks, if you can bear it, as we have said in connection with the apoplexies in the head, and take them out slowly.
Et est super cautelam, ut non incidatur uena, aut neruus.	And it is with great care so that a new wound does not occur, or a nerve.
Et sit spatumile non acutum ualde: ut non addat tibi manum tuam cum incisione, aut inquietet infirmum, et incidas quod non est necesse.	And let the knife be not acute so as to cut deeply: that it may not give you your hand with an incision, or disturb the sick, and you fall down, for it is not necessary.
Si autem incidis uenam, aut arteriam, aut prohibet te ab operatione, tunc pone in uulnus zegi tritum, aut quosdam pulueres qui abscindunt sanguinem, et stringe uulnus, et dimitte ipsum, donec quiescat acuitas apostematis, et mollificetur uulnus: uel incipit et uult putrefieri.	But if you cut a vein or an artery, or prevents you from the operation, then place in the wound a dry piece of wood, or some powder that stops the blood, and tighten the wound, and let go of it until the sharpness subsides from the wound, and the wound softens: or it begins to rot.
Nam sanguis abscinditur tuncia Redi ergo ad operationem tuam, donec compleas.	For the blood is stopped by the poultice; so return to your operation, until you are finished.
Deinde inquire digito tuo indice, si remansit aliquid ex Strophulis aliis paruis: ergo incide eas, et munda eas.	Then inquire with your index finger, if there is anything left of the staphylids or other little things: so cut them and clean them.
Quod si est in radice Strophulae uena magna: tunc oportet ut non incidas illam Strophulam ex radice sua: imo oportet ut liges eam cum filo duplato forti, et dimittas eam donec cadat per se absque nocumento.	For if there is a large staphyle in the root: then it should not be cut by the staphylite from its root: but it should be bound with a strong double thread, and let go until it falls by itself without harm.
Deinde imple uulnus coto ueteri, quod iam submersisti in unguento aegyptio.	Then fill the wound with old cow dung, which you have already soaked in Egyptian ointment.
Deinde cura ipsum.	Then care for the wound.
Si inciditur Strophula tota, tunc oportet ut aggreges labia duo uulneris: et suas ipsum statim, postquam uides quia prorsus non remansit superfluitas.	If the staphyle is whole, then you should gather two sides of the wound: and clean it immediately, as soon as you see that there is no excess.
Si autem uides quod remansit superfluitas propter magnitudinem Strophulae, tunc oportet ut intendas ad incidendam radicem eius, et extrahendam eam: et administra suturam quam diximus.	But if you see that there is excess because of the size of the staphyle, then you should look to cut its root and pull it out: and administer the stitch that we have mentioned.
Et quae ex Strophulis continet humiditates, perfora illam perforatione superficiali: ut appareat tibi locus maturitatis eius: et pone perforationem ab eo quod sequitur inferius corporis, sicut diximus.	And those staphyle that contain moisture, pierce them with a superficial hole: so as to show you the site of maturity of it: and place the hole from that which follows below the body, as we have said.
Deinde administra post perforationem licinia cum unguento, et similia eis, ut corrodat quod remansit ex corruptione, donec quando uides uulnus iam mundatum esse: tunc cura ipsum cum unguento generatiuo carnis, donec sanetur.	Then administer, after the piercing, the licor with ointment, and similar things, so that it may corrode whatever remains of corruption, until such time as you see the wound already cleaned up: then care for the wound with a genera-tive car-nate ointment, until it is healed.
¶ De sectione Epiglotis ab apostemate intra guttur accidente.	¶ On the section of the epiglottis from an accident inside the throat.
Caput XLIII.	¶ On the section of the epiglottis from an accident inside the throat.
Dixerunt antiqui hanc sectionem in Epigloti, et non uidi aliquem in terra nostra, qui eam fecerit: et haec est scriptura sermonis eorum.	The ancient ones described this section of the epiglottis, and no one in our land has done it, who can do it: and this is the writing of their words.
In habentibus autem synanchiam, oportet ut deuitetur sectio Epiglotis: cum non fiat iuuamentum per illud: propterea, quod omnes uenae et pulmo sunt infirmi.	In those who have a synanche, the section of the epiglottis should be removed: for it is not done by it: therefore, because all the tonsils and lungs are dormant.
In illis uero qui habent apostema calidum in ore, aut gutture, aut duabus amigdalis, quando non est aegritudo in cannali, oportet uti sectione Epiglotis, ad fugiendum ex perditione quae fit ex praefocatione.	In those who have a hot swelling in the mouth, or in the throat, or in the two Almonds, when there is no disease in the canal, it is necessary to use the section of the epiglottis, in order to escape the loss which happens from the pre-condensation.
Oportet ergo quando uolumus illud, ut secemus Epiglotim sub tribus circulis Epiglotis, aut quatuor, sectione parua per latitudinem, in eo quod est inter duos circulos per quantitatem, quod sit sectio in sifac, non in cartilagine: et iste quidem locus est conueniens sectioni, quoniam est priuatus carne, et uasa sanguinis ab eo sunt longinqua.	Therefore, when we want to cut that [epiglottis], let us cut it with a small knife under the circle of the epiglottis, or four, with a small section across the width, in that which is between the two circles by measure, that it be a section in the sifac, not in the cartilage: and this place is convenient for the section, because it is separated from the flesh, and the blood vessels are far away from it.
Quod si medicator est timidus, tunc oportet ut extendat cutem gutturis cum uncino.	That if the doctor is shy, then it is necessary to extend the skin of the throat with a hook.
Deinde findat cutem, donec quando peruenit ad cannalem: deuitet uas sanguinis, si uidet ex eis aliquid.	Then he should find the skin, until he reaches when it goes into the canal: he should tie the blood vessels, if he sees any of them.
Deinde secet sifac quod narrauimus: et significatur super sectionem cannalis ex phlegmate quod egreditur ex ea, cum eo quod disrumpitur, et abscisione uocis.	Then let him cut the sifac that we have mentioned: and it is shown on the section of the canal from the phlegm which comes out of it, when it stops [the flow], and from the loss of voice by the abruption.
Et dimitte uulnus apertum tempore aliquo.	And let go of the knot at some time.
Cum ergo remouetur hora in qua timetur praefocatio, aggrega duo labia uulneris cutis, et sue ipsam solam absque cartilagine.	When therefore the hour comes when there is a fear of pre-condensation, let the two lips of the wound of the skin be gathered together, and let it itself be cut alone without the cartilage.
Deinde administra medicinas quae faciunt nasci carnem, usquequo sanetur.	Then administer the medicines which make meat grow, until it is healed.
Inquit Albucasis.	He said: "Albucasis.
Summa huius sermonis quem narrauimus, expositio non est, nisi quando uident, quod aliquod horum apostematum iam opilauit guttur infirmi: et sublimatus est infirmus super mortem, et uult intersecari anhelitus eius: uadunt ad secandum Epiglotim, ut respiret infirmus super locum uulneris quadam respiratione, et saluetur a morte: et propter hoc praeceperunt dimittere uulnus apertum, donec consumatur malicia aegritudinis, et est malicia eius tribus diebus, et quasi ipsa: tunc ergo praecaeperunt suere uulnus, et curare ipsum, donec sanetur.	Inquired Albucasis.
Et illud quod uidi per me ipsum est, quod una ancilla accaepit cultellum, et misit cum in guttur suum, et incidit cum eo partem cannalis pulmonis.	And that which I saw through myself is that a slave took a knife and put it in her throat and struck it with it on a part of the lung canal.
Et uocatus sum ad curationem eius, et inueni eam mugire, sicut est mugitus mortui.	And I was called to cure her, and I found that she was snoring, as is the snore of the dead.
Detexi ergo a uulnere, et inueni sanguinem qui egressus fuerat ex uulnere paruum.	So I took off the bandage, and I found blood which had come out from the small wound.
Confisus ergo sum, quod ipsa non absciderat uenam, neque guidegi: et uentus egrediebatur ex uulnere.	So I was confused that she had not cut a vein nor an artery, and wind came out from the wound.
Properaui ergo, et sui uulnus, et curaui ipsum, donec sanum est: et non accidit ancillae aliquid, nisi raucedo in uoce: et rediit post dies ad meliorem dispositionum suarum.	So I sewed up the wound, and I cared for him until he was well: and nothing happened to the slave except that her voice became hoarse: and she recovered her health after a few days.
Hinc ergo dico: quod in sectione Epiglotis non est timor.	So therefore I say: that there is no fear in the section of Epiglottis.
¶ De sectione Herniae gutturis.	Regarding the section of the Gut:
Caput XLIIII.	Head 44.
Hoc Apostema nominatum Hernia gutturis, est apostema magnum, secundum colorem corporis: et est in mulieribus multum.	This condition called Hernia Gutturis is a large hernia, of the color of the body: and it is common in women.
Et est secundum duos modos: aut enim est naturale: aut est accidentale.	And it has two forms: either it is natural: or it is accidental.
In naturali certe non est ingenium.	Certainly, there is no talent.
Accidentale uero est secundum duos modos: quorum unus est similis nodis pinguibus.	On the other hand, it is accidental and has two forms, one of which is similar to the nodules of the lungs, and the other...
Et modus alter, est similis apostemati quod fit ex nodatione arteriae.	And the other form is similar to a hernia that is caused by an enlargement of an artery.
Et in ipso est timor, et non oportet ut praesumptio fiat ad ipsum cum ferro, nisi in eo quod est paruum: et tu proba ipsum, et inuestiga ipsum cum Intromisso.	And there is a fear in it, and it should not be assumed that it should be made with iron unless it is small: and you test it, and investigate it with intrusion.
Si ergo inuenis ipsum simile nodo pingui, et non est suspensum cum aliqua uenarum: tunc seca ipsum, sicut secantur nodi: et extrahe ipsum cum eo quod continet ex kisti, si est in kisti: et si non, tunc perscrutare totum eius.	If then the swelling is a similar thick knot, and it is not suspended with any veins: then dry out the swelling, as they dry out knots: and draw out the swelling with what holds it in the container, if it is in a container: and if not, then examine all of it.
Deinde cura locum cum eo quod oportet ex curatione, donec sanetur.	Then take care of the place with what needs to be done from the cure, until it heals.
¶ De sectione super species Nodorum.	§ On Sectioning Above Kinds of Knots.
Caput XLV.	CHAPTER XLV.
Nodorum multae sunt species, et ego iam dixi omnes species eorum in diuisione: et oportet ut narrem hic differentiam inter Nodum, et Exituram: cum sit dubitationem faciens.	There are many kinds of knots, and I have already spoken about them in a general way: it is necessary for me to speak here of the difference between Knots and Swelling, since there is some doubt about them.
Dico ergo, quod cum Exitura est caliditas, et febris, et dolores uehementes, donec sedatur ebullitio superfluitatis, et completur putrefactio: tunc enim quiescunt febris et calor.	I say then that when Swelling is hot, and feverish, and sharp pains are severe, until the excess fluid runs out, and decay is complete: for then the fever and heat subside.
Cum Nodo uero non est caliditas, neque febris, neque dolores, et continet eos kistis sifachin, qui est eis saccus proprius, et est secundum colorem corporis: et est incaeptio eorum sicut cicer, et fit sicut batecha, et maior et minor.	But when Knot is not hot, nor feverish, nor are there pains, and it holds them in the skin sacs of its own flesh, which is like a sack to them, and has the color of the body: and they are like beans, and resemble a mat, and are greater or smaller.
Et sunt secundum duas species: aut pingues: aut continent humiditatem.	And they are in two kinds: either they are fat: or they hold moisture.
Et colores humiditatis sunt multi, secundum quod dixi in diuisione.	And the colors of moisture are many, as I have said in a general way.
Oportet ergo, quando peruenis ad curationem Nodi, ut experiaris eum, et inquiras ipsum in primis cum instrumento quod nominatur Intromissum, secundum quod ueniet forma eius in capitulo quod est post hoc.	It is necessary then, when you are treating a Knot, that you examine it and inquire into it by means of the instrument called Intromissum, according to the shape of it in the chapter which follows this.
Et modus inquisitionis apostematum, et Nodorum omnium est, ut accipias hoc instrumentum, et intromittas ipsum in humidiorem locum, quem inuenis in apostemate: et tu reuolue digitos tuos cum eo paulatim, donec scias quod instrumentum iam penetrauit cutem.	And the method of inquiry into swelled parts, and all Knots, is that you take this instrument, and insert it into the moistened place in which the swelling is: and you move your fingers slowly with it, until you are sure that the instrument has entered the skin.
Deinde ultima manum tuam secundum mensuram magnitudinis apostematis.	Then bring the last hand of yours according to the size of the swelling.
Deinde extrahe Intromissum, et considera illud quod egrediur in uestigio eius.	Then take out Intromissum, and look at what comes out with it into the opening.
Si ergo egreditur humiditas currens, quicunque color sit: tunc seca ipsum sectione superficiali, secundum quod dixi in reliquis apostematibus.	If then a running moisture is discharged, let it be of any color: then make him dry by the superficial incision, as I said in the other pustules.
Et si non egreditur humiditas in uestigio Intromissi, tunc scias quia est pinguis: seca ergo super ipsum sectione habente formam crucis, secundum formam hanc, sicut docui te: et suspende ipsum cum uncinis, et excoria cutem ab omni parte cum facilitate: et custodi kistin si potes super illud, ut extrahas ipsam sanam cum Nodo.	And if there is no discharge of moisture in the wound with an incision, then you will know that it is thick: so dry above the wound with a cross-shaped section, according to this form, as I have taught you: and suspend the body with hooks, and scrub the skin from all parts with ease: and guard the wound with a towel if you can over it, so that you draw out what is healthy with a knot.
Si autem disrumpitur kistis apud operationem, et non est possibile extrahere ipsam sanam, multotiens enim accidit illud, tunc extrahe ipsam frustatim, donec non remaneat ex ea aliquid.	If the skin is broken during the operation, and it is not possible to draw out what is healthy, because this often happens, then draw it out in pieces until there remains nothing of it.
Nam si remanet ex ea aliquid parum, aut multum, redit Nodus secundum plurimum.	For if there remains a little or a lot of it, the knot will come back according to many accounts.
Quod si uincit te, et remanet ex eo parum: tunc imple uulnus apud completionem tuam, quibusdam pulueribus corrosiuis acutis: et stringe uulnus, et pone supra ipsum quod sedet apostema calidum, et cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	That if it should pinch you, and there remains a little of it: then fill the incision with some acute corrosive powder: and tighten the ligature, and place it on top of the spot that sits next to the pustule, and take care of the wound with the rest of the cure, until it is healed.
Si ergo est Nodus magnus, tunc sue duo labia eius, et cura ipsum cum eo quod incarnat.	And if there is a large knot, then cut it in two places, and take care of the flesh that has grown with it.
Si autem est tibi contraria uena pulsatilis, aut non pulsatilis: tunc propera, et imple locum zegi trito, et dimitte ipsum strictum duobus diebus, aut tribus, donec putrefiat uulnus, et quiescat ebullitio sanguinis: deinde redi ad incidendum illud quod remansit ex Nodo.	If then there is a reverse shape that pulses or does not pulse: then approach it, and fill the place to be incised with fresh, dry earth, and leave it tied for two days, or three, until the ligature putrefies, and the swelling subsides: then return to cutting out what remains of the knot.
¶ De foris instrumentorum pro sectione et perforatione.	Regarding instruments from outside for cutting and piercing.
Caput XLVI.	Chapter LVI.
EX Eis sunt formae Intromissorum, et sunt trium specierum.	Of the three types of incision, there are three forms.
Ex eis enim est magnum, et ex eis est medium, et ex eis est paruum.	For from these there is a large one, and from these there is a middle one, and from these there is a small one.
Fiant ex ferro alfulud quadratarum extremitatum decenter, ut festinent introitum in apostemate.	Let there be made of iron four square ends, so that they may push into the pustule from the outside.
Et istae sunt formae Experientium, et no, id est, perforantia: et unum eorum nominatur beris, idest, peforans: et sunt trium specierum.	And these are the forms of incisions, and no, that is to say, perforations: and one of them is called béris, that is, perforans: and there are three species.
Ex eis enim est magnum, et medium, et paruum.	From these, indeed, is the great one, and the middle, and the little.
Conueniunt, ut inuestigentur per ea apostemata, et exiturae, et fistulae, et bubones ab eo quod inter ea est ex ossibus.	Convezione, that they be investigated by these openings, and exits, and sutures, and abscesses from him since it is among them from the bones.
Et aliis fiunt rotunda, tersa, lenia, sicut acus magnae quibus subsellia suuntur, ex citrino scilicet, aut ex aere, aut ferro, aut argento.	And others are round, and smooth, and soft, as the large aiguille with which they are sutured, from citron indeed, or from bronze, or from iron, or from silver.
Et meliora eorum sunt quae fiunt ex citrino.	And better of them are those that are made from citron.
Et fiunt Experientia etiam de plumbo nigro, quae conueniunt ut per ea experiantur fistulae, quarum concauitate sunt reflexiones, ut reflectantur cum lenitate sua cum illis reflexionibus.	And are also the incisions of black lead, which are convenient that they be investigated by these openings, whose reflections are soft, so that they reflect with their softness to those reflections.
Et sunt iterum trium specierum.	And again there are three species.
Quoniam ex eis sunt longa, ex eis media, et ex eis breuia, secundum quantitatem amplitudinis fistulae et stricturae eius.	For from these are long, from these are middle, and from these are short, according to the quantity of the width of the fistula and the strictness of its.
Forma Vncinorum, et sunt multarum specierum.	Shape of the vulturine, and there are many species.
Quoniam ex eis sunt simplices, scilicet quibus est curuitas una: et sunt trium specierum sicut uides, Magni, Medii, et Parui.	For from these are simple, that is to say, with one curvature: and there are three species as you see, Great, Middle, and Small.
Et ex eis sunt Vncini caeci: et sunt trium specierum.	And from these are vulturine blind: and there are three species.
Et ex eis sunt uncini habentes duas curuaturas, et sunt trium specierum: et ex eis sunt uncini habentes tres curuaturas, et sunt trium specierum: et omnes isti sunt necessarii in loco suo.	And from these have two curvatures, and there are three species: and from these have three curvatures, and there are three species: and all of these are necessary in their place.
Et istae sunt formae Scalpellorum, quibus secantur et excoriantur Nodi, et apostemata: et sunt trium specierum: quoniam ex eis est magnum, medium, et paruum.	And these are the forms of scalpels, with which they cut and scald nods, and openings: and there are three species: for from these is the great one, and the middle, and the little.
Eorum extremitates quibus fit sectio sunt acutae, extremitates aliae sunt non acutae: et non ponuntur taliter, nisi ut cum eis fiat iuuamentum in excoriatione Nodorum apud timorem incisionis uenae, aut nerui: et ut sanetur per ea infirmus, et inueniat tranquillitatem parumper ex adustione quam inuenit apud excoriationem apostematis.	Their extremities with which is made the section are acute, other extremities are not acute: and they do not put so much, unless it is done with them that there is a iuuementum in the scalding of nods at the fear of an incision of flesh, or nerve: and to cure per it through them that sickens, and finds some quietness from the drying out than it finds in the scald of openings.
Istae sunt Magda, et sunt specierum trium.	These are the six types and three species.
Fiunt ex aere, et sunt similia Radio, cum quo fit alcohol: et in extremitate lata est puncta Spatumilis occultata: et in ea currit ad interiora, et ad exteriora quando uis, sicut uides.	These are made of air, and they are similar to the ray of light, from which alcohol is formed, and at its end there is a hidden, thin, invisible line: it runs to the inside and outside when you look at it, just as you see.
Forma Spatumilium quae absconduntur inter digitos apud perforationem apostematum: et non percipiunt ea infirmi: et sunt trium specierum, magnum, medium, et paruum.	The form of the needle that is hidden between the fingers near the hole of the blisters: and it is not felt by the nurses: and there are three kinds, large, medium, and small.
Fomae Ventosarum cum quibus abscinditur fluxus sanguinis: et sunt trium specierum, magnae, mediae, et paruae.	The forms of the wind pipe with which blood flow is cut off: and they are three species, large, medium, and small.
Fiant ex aere, aut citrino, rotundae, ad longitudinem parumper, sicut uides: et sint ad subtilitatem.	Let them be made of air, or yellow, round, about the same length, as you see: and let them be in terms of thinness.
Et oportet ut sint istae species Ventosarum apud te magnae, et paruae: ut abscindas per eas sanguinem cum uelocitate apud necessitatem, et tunc quando non est tibi praesens medicina.	And let these be the kinds of wind pipes in you, large and small: so that you cut off blood with speed at need, and then when there is no medicine present with you.
Verumtamen non utaris eis in abscisione sanguinis in omni loco corporis, et non utaris nisi in locis carnosis: sicut lacertis cruris, et coxae, et lacertis brachiorum, et mammillarum, et uentris, et inguinum, et similibus eis, ex lacertis carnosis, humidis.	However, do not use them to cut off blood anywhere in the body, and do not use them except in the fleshy places: such as the legs of the reptiles, and the hips, and the wrists of the arms, and the nipples, and the palms of the hands, and the thighs, and similar to these, from the fleshy parts of the reptile, moist.
Et quandoque fiunt ex eis instrumenta parua alia similia corticibus fisticorum, secundum suam formam: quibus abscinditur sanguis quando fluit ex loco phlebotomiae, aut apud incisionem uenae, aut arteriae: et quandoque fiunt ex eis rotundae secundum hanc formam.	And sometimes they become small tools like the knuckle of the fist, according to their form: from which blood is cut off when it flows from a phlebotomy place, or at a wound on a vein, or an artery: and sometimes they are made round, according to this shape.
¶ De cura Mammillarum hominum quae mammillis mulierum assimilantur.	The care of the nipples of men, which are like the nipples of women:
Caput XLVII.	Chapter LVII.
Quandoque inflantur Mammillae quorundam hominum apud complementum somni (id est, cum incipiunt pollui in somno) donec similantur mammillis mulierum: et remanent apostemosae foede.	When certain men's nipples fill up when they begin to sleep until they resemble women's nipples: and the blisters remain full of milk.
Qui ergo abhorret illud, oportet ut secet super mammillas sectione lunari, secundum hanc formam ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. Deinde excoria pinguedinem totam.	Whoever therefore hates that thing, let him cut off the whole nipple with a lunar saw, according to this form from the line, b, to the line, g: and then scrape the callous skin all over.
Postea imple uulnus ex medicamine incarnatiuo.	Afterwards fill the wound with incarnated medicine.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then join together the two lips of the wound with sutures, and care for it until it is healed.
Si autem declinat mammilla ad inferiora, et mollificatur propter magnitudinem suam, sicut accidit mulieribus: tunc oportet ut findatur in duobus lateribus suis superioribus duabus sectionibus similibus figurae lunari, quarum unaquaeque continetur cum altera apud fines utriusque, donec sit linea maior continens minorem, secundum hanc formam ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. Postea excoria cutem quae est inter duo labia, et aufer pinguedinem, et administra quod diximus de sutura et pulueribus, quod est necessarium ex curatione, donec sanetur.	If however the nipple turns downward to the lower side, and becomes soft because of its size, as happens to women: then it is necessary that two similar lunar shapes be found on either side of its two upper sides, each held by the other at their ends until they meet in one line, like this form from a line, b. on the line, g. Then remove the skin which is between the two lips, and cut off the nipple, and administer what we have said about sutures and powders, which is necessary for healing, until it is healed.
Si autem non comples incisionem eius quod oportet te incidere, propter inquietudinem infirmi, aut propter fluxum sanguinis: tunc oportet ut impleas uulnus coto submerso unguento corrosiuo, et dimitte ipsum, donec corrodat illud quod remansit ex pinguedine.	If however you do not meet the incision which it is necessary to make on him, because of nursing unease, or because of bleeding: then it is necessary that you fill the wound with corroding submerged ointment, and leave it alone until it has corroded what remained of the nipple.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for it, until it is healed.
¶ De perforatione apostematis, quod accidit sub Titillico.	Perforation in a wart, which happens under the nipple.
Caput XLVIII.	Chapter LXVIII.
Ista apostemata quae accidunt sub Titillico, sunt ex speciebus Strophularum dura, quae continet kistis, et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditates.	These warts which happen under the nipple are of the hard species of warts, which contain blisters, and from these come those which contain moisture.
Quae ergo sunt ex eis quae continent humiditates, oportet ut secentur sectione lunari, secundum hanc formam, ex linea b. ad lineam, g. cum ergo euacuatur totum quod est in apostemate ex sanie, tunc imple ipsum coto ueteri, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	Since however these are of the species which contain moisture, it is necessary that they be cut with a lunar section, according to this form, from a line, b. to a line, g. When therefore all that is in the wart has been drained, then fill it with aged ointment, and leave it alone until another day.
Deinde auferatur cotum, et curetur cum unguento conueniente ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then remove the aged ointment, and care for it with the suitable ointment, until it is healed.
Quod si apostema fuerit ex specie nodorum Strophularum, tunc scinde super ipsum, sicut diximus in sectione super Strophulas aequaliter.	If however the wart is of the species of nodules of warts, then cut over it, as we said above, in a section of warts equal to each other.
Si autem extenditur uulnus in hoc ut emittat pus, tunc administra in eo cauterium, secundum quod diximus in eo quod praemissum est.	If, however, the fracture is extended in this way so that it discharges pus, then administer cautery to it, as we have said above, since it is premised.
¶ De sectione apostematis quod accidit propter Arteriam et Venam.	§ On the Section of Abscesses Which Occurs Because of an Artery and a Vein.
Caput XLIX.	ヘッドXLVIII。
Quando disrumpitur Arteria, et consolidatur cutis quae est supra eam, tuno multotiens accidit inde apostema: et similiter accidit Venae etiam, ut accidat in ea apostema et inflatio.	When an artery is broken and the skin that is above it is hardened, then sometimes much infection occurs from there; and also with veins, so that infection and swelling occur from them.
Et signa quibus cognoscitur, quod apostema et inflatio sint propter Arteriam et Venam, sunt: quoniam, quando apostema est propter arteriam, est longum, aggregatum in profundo corporis: et quando impellis apostema digits tuis, sentis quasi sit ei stridor.	And the signs by which it is known that an abscess and swelling are because of an artery and a vein, are as follows. Because, when an abscess is because of an artery, it is long, gathered in the depths of the body: and when the swelling of the digits of your hand feels like it has a whirring sound,
Et illud quod est propter Venam, est rotundum in manifesto corporis.	And that which is because of a vein is round, clearly visible on the body.
Et sectio super hoc apostema est error, et praecipue quod est sub ascellis, et inguinibus, et collo, et in locis multis corporis: et est magnum ualde.	And the section on this abscess is an error, and especially if it is under the armpits, and in the groin, and in the neck, and in many other places of the body; and it is great indeed.
Oportet ergo ut deuitetur eius cura cum ferro, et quod ex eis etiam est in extremitatibus, aut in capite, oportet ut deuitetur.	Therefore, so that its care is removed with iron, and that from it too, in the extremities or in the head, so that it is removed.
Super illud ergo quod ex eis est ex inflatione orificii Arteriae, finde in cute sectione in longitudine.	On this, then, which is because of swelling from an artery opening, find on the skin in length.
Deinde aperi sectionem cum uncinis, postea Arteriam: et libera eam ex tunicis, donec detegatur.	Then open the section with a hook, then expose the artery: and free it from the tunics, until it is discovered.
Deinde intromitte sub ea acum, et fac eam penetrare usque ad latus aliud, et stringe Arteriam cum filo duplo in duobus locis, secundum quod docui te in extractione duarum Arteriarum quae sunt in timporibus.	Then introduce under it a sharp tool, and let it penetrate to the side opposite: and tie the artery with a double knot in two places, as I taught you in the extraction of two arteries which are in the temple.
Deinde punge locum, qui est inter duo ligamenta cum spatumili, donec egrediatur sanguis qui est in eo totus, et soluatur apostema.	Then poke the place that is between the two ligaments with a needle, until blood comes out of it all, and dissolve the abscess.
Deinde administra curationem quae generat pus, donec cadant ligamenta: postea cura illud cum unguentis conuenientibus ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then administer the cure which generates pus, until the ligaments are broken: then treat that with oils fitting for it, until it heals.
Quod si fuerit apostema propter sectionem Venae, tunc oportet ut teneas manu tua quod tibi possibile est ex apostemate cum cute.	If it is an apostema due to the sectioning of a vein, then you should hold your hand as much as possible without hurting yourself from the apostema with the skin.
Deinde intromitte acum sub loco quem tenuisti manu tua, et fac eam penetrare: et sit in ea filum duplum, donec extrahas ipsum ex latere altero.	Then introduce an acorn under the spot where you held your hand and let it pierce: and let it enter to the depth of two threads, until you draw it out from the other side.
Deinde liga cum ipso apostema ligamento bono: secundum quod dixi tibi in ligamento uuae, a duabus partibus cum duabus extremitatibus fili.	Then bind the aposteme with good ligature: according to what I told you in the ligature of uvea, from both parts with both extremities of thread.
Si autem times quod extrahatur filum, tunc intromitte acum aliam cum filo alio sub apostemate toto apud incisionem acus: preme, et stringe fila tua in quatuor locis.	If you are to pull out a thread, then introduce another acorn with another thread under the aposteme throughout the incision of the ace: press, and squeeze your threads in four places.
Deinde seca apostema in medio sui, donec quando egreditur quod in eo est: tunc incide superfluitatem cutis, et dimitte quod ligatum est ex ea.	Then dry up the aposteme in the middle of itself until it comes out what is inside: then cut off the surplus skin, and let go what is bound from it.
Deinde pone super ipsum puluillum quem submersisti in uino, et oleo.	Then put on top a little wool that you immersed in wine, and oil.
Deinde administra curationem, quae fit cum liciniis et unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then administer the cure, which is done with ligatures and ointments, until it heals.
¶ De apostemate quod accidit ex torsione Neruorum.	The aposteme that happens from twisting of the nerves.
Caput L.	Head.
Sicut accidit apostema in Arteria et Vena, similiter accidit apostema in Neruis: quod accidit in eis percussio, aut accidit a labore superfluo, et similibus: et fit plurimum illis in locis adiutoriorum, aut calcanei, et in omni loco in quo mouentur iuncturae: et est apostema graue.	As has happened with the artery and vein, so it has happened with the nerves: which has happened from hitting or from excessive work, and similar: and it often happens to them in places of support, or calcanei, and in any place where joints move: and it is a gray apostema.
Similatur color eius reliquo corpori, et est in pluribus dispositionibus absque dolore: et quando stringitur cum uehementia, sentit in eo infirmus simile stupori.	Its color resembles the rest of the body, and it is in many dispositions without pain: and when it is squeezed with a pulsation, it feels in it a similar stupor.
Et non est apostema aggregatum in profundo corporis, imo est sub cute, et ipsum mouetur ad omnem partem, et non uadit ad anteriora, uel ante, neque retro ad posteriora.	And this apostema is not agregatum in the depth of the body, but it lies under the skin, and moves all parts, and does not stick to the front, or before, or behind.
Quod ergo ex eis est in iuncturis, non oportet ut inuadatur cum ferro.	So whatever is in the joints, should not be moved with a iron.
Fortasse enim accidet contractio.	Perhaps, however, it happens contraction.
In illo autem quod ex eis est in capite, aut in fronte, finde cutem cum spatumili.	In that place, however, which is on the head, or on the forehead, find flesh with a hammerhead.
Si ergo est apostema paruum, tunc tene ipsum cum forficibus, et abscinde ipsum a radice.	If then there is a small hematoma, then hold it with forceps and cut it off from the root.
Et si est magnum, tunc suspende ipsum eum uncino, et excoria ipsum: deinde aufer ipsum, et aggrega uulnus cum sutura: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	And if it is large, then suspend it with a hook and scrape it off: then take it away, and gather the wound with a stitch: and care for it, until it is healed.
¶ De sectione apostematis, quod accidit in uentre.	§ On the removal of hematomas, which occur in the abdomen.
Caput LI.	Chapter LII.
Accidunt quibusdam hominibus multotiens in uentribus eorum, et in reliquis corporibus ipsorum, thelil, quae nominantur Fungalia, per similitudinem ipsorum cum fungis.	Some people often have little spots in their stomachs and other parts of their bodies that are called ringworms by some, because they resemble worms.
Quorum radix est subtilis, et ipsorum caput est grossum, et conuersa sunt labia eorum.	Their roots are small, but their heads are thick, and their lips are large.
Et est ex eis paruum: et est ex eis quod magnificatur ualde.	And some of them are small; and some of them grow very large.
Et ego quidem iam uidi uirum, et in uentre eius erant duo thelil, quae erant magis quam rebus aliis similia fungis: non erat differentia inter ea, alba, minutae radicis, et inuersabantur labia eorum, et findebantur, et humiditas currebat ex eis semper.	And I have already seen a man, and there were two ringworms in his abdomen, which were more like other things than fungi: there was no difference between them, they were white, had small roots, and their lips projected, and always had moisture flowing from them.
Incidi ergo ea, et inueni in pondere unius quasi X et VIII uncia et in altero quasi VI uncia Et operatio in incisione eorum est, ut consideres tunc, si infirmus est humidus, et color thelil est albus, humidum, subtilis radicis: tunc incide ipsum cum spatumili lato, et sint in praesentia tua cauteria in igne.	Then cut them open, and you will find in the weight of one almost X pounds and 8 ounces, and in the other almost VI pounds; and the operation on them is, that you should consider then, if they are sickly and moist, and the color of the ringworms is white, moist, with small roots: then cut them open with a hammerhead, and let there be before your eyes cauterization by fire.
Multotiens enim expellitur apud sectionem eius sanguis multus: propera ergo si te uincit sanguis, tunc cauteriza ipsum.	For often much blood is expelled in the section; therefore, if blood overpowers you, then cauterize it.
Quod si uides infirmum pauidum et timidum ab incisione cum ferro, tunc accipe filum ex plumbo decenter factum, et stringe cum eo athelul: cuius modus est quem diximus, et dimitte ipsum duobus diebus.	That if you see a sick and frightened man overcome by the cut with an iron knife, then take a piece of copper wire that is bent, and tie it with it: for this method has been described above, and let it go for two days.
Deinde adde in strictura plumbi.	Then add to the tightness of the copper wire.
Non ergo cesses stringere plumbum, quotiens imprimit in thelil, donec abscindatur, et cadat per se absque labore.	Therefore do not cease to bind up lead, whenever it impresses on the flesh, until it is cut off, and falls away by itself without labor.
Si autem thelil grossae fuerit radicis, tunc in incisione eius est quiddam timoris et pauoris: praecipue quod est in uentre.	But if the lump is large at the root, then there is something of fear and worry in its incision: especially because it is in the belly.
Verumtamen possibile est, ut incidas medietatem eius.	However, it is possible that you cut off half of it.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum, ut non redeat.	Then cauterize it so that it does not return.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur uulnus.	Then take care of the wound so that it heals well.
Et caue ne praesumas incidere thelil quod est fusci coloris, pauci sensus, foedi aspectus: ipsum enim est apostema cancerosum: et ego ueniam cum rememoratione Cancri post hoc.	And do not consider that the lump which is of a dark color, has few senses, and a fatty appearance: for it is an apostemic cancer: and I come to mind when I remember Cancer after this.
¶ De cura eminentiae Vmbilici.	§ On the treatment of prominent umbilicus.
Caput LII.	Head II.
Fit eminentia Vmbilici ex caussis multis.	Emblem of umbilicus from many causes.
Aut ex fissuris sifac, quod super uentrem est: et exit ex eo althub, aut intestinum, secundum quod accidit in reliquis rupturis.	Or from a breach of the skin which is on the belly: and it comes out of it as an inchworm, or from the intestines, according to what happens in the other ruptures.
Aut ex sanguine qui fluit ex Vena, aut ex Arteria, secundum quod praemissum est.	Or from blood which flows from a vein, or from an artery, according to what has been said above.
Aut ex uentositate coartata in eo.	Or from a coarctation of the windpipe in it.
Si autem est propter fissuram sifac, et exitum thirbi: tunc est color apostematis similis colori corporis: et est lene, absque dolore: et apparet diuersi situs.	But if it is from a breach of the skin which is clean, and it emerges slowly: then it is the color of an apostle like the color of the body: and it is soft, without pain: and it shows various shapes.
Et si est propter egressionem intestini, tunc est situs eius, cum eo quod narrauimus, uehementioris diuersitatis.	And if it is from an exit of the intestines, then its location is with what we have described, and it becomes more varied in its shape.
Cum ergo tu premis ipsum digitis tuis, occultatur: deinde redit, et fortasse est cum eo sonitus: et magnificatur multum apud introitum balnei, et laborem uehaementum.	But when you press it with your fingers, it hides: then it returns, and perhaps there is a sound with it: and it magnifies much at the entrance of hair, and sounds harsh.
Si uero est propter humiditatem, est lene, tunc non occultatur quando premis ipsum manu tua, neque constringium, neque additur.	But if it is because of moisture, it is soft, then it does not hide when pressed with your hand, and does not constrict, and is not added to.
Quod si est propter sanguinem, tunc cum istis signis apparet apostema ad nigredinem de cliue.	That if it is because of blood, then with these signs an aposteme appears towards blackening from the root.
Si autem est propter carnem natam: tunc est apostema graue, grossum, durum, et figitur secundum quantitatem unam.	But if it is born of flesh: then it is a hard apotheosis, coarse, tough, and it figures according to one quantity.
Si uero est propter uentositatem, tunc tactus eius est lenis.	But if it is because of the wind: then his touch is soft.
Et operatio in illo est, ut consideres tunc, si eminentia umbilici est propter sanguinem Arteriae, aut Venae, aut uentositatem: tunc oportet ut prohibearis a curatione eius.	And the operation in that is, when you consider then, if the umbilical eminence is because of blood of an artery or vein or wind: then you should prohibit him from the cure of it.
Nam in illo est timor et pauor, sicut docui te in capitulo, in quo dixi apostemata propter arteriam et uenam.	For in that is fear and fear, as I taught you in the chapter, where I said that apotheoses are because of the artery and the vein.
Quod si eminentia umbilici est propter intestinum, aut zirbum: tunc oportet ut praecipias infirmo, quatenus teneat anhelitum suum, et stet stans extensus.	That if the umbilical eminence is because of the intestines or liver: then you should prescribe to the sick person that he keep his breath and stand erect.
Deinde signa cum encaustro in circumitu umbilici totius.	Then signs with the caustum around the navel of all.
Postea praecipe ei, ut resupinetur inter manus tuas super dorsum suum.	Then prescribe to him that he lie on his back between your hands.
Deinde circunda cum spatumili lato in circumitu umbilici super locum quem signasti cum encaustro.	Then with a sponge wet with water around the navel on the place that you marked with the caustic.
Postea extende medium apostematis ad superiora, cum uncino magno.	Then extend the middle apotheosis to the upper part with a large hook.
Deinde liga eum in circumitu forti cum filo, aut cum chorda de serico ligamento firmo: et sit nodus ligamenti alenxotati.	Then bind him strongly around with thread, or with a silk cord that is strong: and let the knot of the binding be relaxed.
Deinde aperi medium apostematis extensum supra ligamentum.	Then open the middle apotheosis that you have extended above the ligament.
Si ergo inueneris ipsum iam captum a ligamento: tunc extrahe alenxotati, et intromitte in ipsum digitum indicem, et impelle intestinum ad interiora uentris: et si inueneris zirbum, tunc accipe ipsum cum uncino, et incide superfluitatem eius.	But if you find him already captured by the ligament: then remove the relaxed one, and stick your finger into him, and push the intestines toward the inner side of the navel: and if you find the liver: then take him with a hook, and cut off the excess.
Si autem contraria est tibi arteria, aut uena: tunc circunda ipsum multum.	But if it is the opposite for you: an artery or vein: then bind him closely.
Deinde redi ad operationem tuam.	Then return to your operation.
Et accipe duas acus, et intromitte in eis duo fila fortia: et intromitte duas acus in circumitu quem fecisti circa apostema in modum crucis, quas facis penetrare.	And take two pins, and stick two strong wires into them: and stick two pins around the mark that you made around the apotheosis in the form of a cross, which you make to pierce through.
Deinde stringe apostema in quatuor locis super acus: et si uis, aufer acus, et dimitte locum, donec putrefiat caro extensa: et cadat per se: aut incide ipsam quando subtiliatur et putrefit.	Then tighten the apotheosis in four places on the pins: and if you want to, remove the pins, and let the place remain until the flesh that is extended putrifies: and it will fall by itself: or cut it off when it becomes thin and putrid.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod oportet ex unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then the care of himself with the ointment until he is healed.
Quod si eminentia umbilici est ex carne nara in eo, aut ex humiditate: tunc oportet ut concaues apostema, sicut diximus.	If the umbilical cord is embedded in the flesh or in moisture: then you should let the abscess drain as we have said.
Et extrahas sanguinem, aut humiditatem, quam inuenis in eo.	And extract the blood or moisture that has entered it.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod solidat locum.	Then the care of himself with the ointment until he is healed.
¶ De cura CANCRI.	DE: Curas cancri sunt multae et variarum, sicut et tota cura morbis.
Caput LIII.	CHAPTER LIII: The Care of Cancer.
Iam diximus in diuisione species Cancri, et qualiter est uia ad curationem eius cum medicinis: et cauendum ab eo cum curatione eius cum ferro, ut non ulceretur: et diximus Cancrum generatum in matrice, et cautelam a curatione eius.	DE CURE CANCRI: De cure of cancer are many and varied, as also is the way to cure it with medicine: and guard against cura it with iron, lest it ulcerate: and we have spoken of how cancer is generated in the womb, and of the need for caution in curing it.
Et dixerunt antiqui, quod quandoque Cancer est in loco, ubi possibilis est eius eradicatio: sicut Cancer qui est in mammillis, aut in coxa, et eis similibus, ex membris locatis ad extrahendum totum eius: praecipue quando est incipiens paruus.	And the ancients say that sometimes cancer can be eradicated when it is in a place where it can be completely removed: like cancer in the breast or the thigh and similar places from a member located to extract all of it: especially when it is only beginning to bud.
Quando uero antiquatur, et est magnus, non oportet ut appropinques ei.	When, however, it has taken deep root and is great, it is not necessary to approach it closely.
Ego enim non potui sanare ex eo aliquem: neque uidi alium ante me qui peruenerit ad illud.	For I could not cure myself of it, nor did I see anyone else who had been cured of it.
Et operatio in eo, quando est locatus sicut diximus, est, ut praecedas, et soluas infirmum ex cholera nigra aliquotiens.	And the operation upon him, when he is located as we have said, is, as it were, to follow on and dissolve illness from black cholera sometimes.
Deinde phlebotoma ipsum si inuenis cum repletione manifesta.	Then let blood from himself if it is evidently filled with blood.
Deinde praepara infirmum praeparatione, in qua locetur cum operatione.	Then prepare the sick with a preparation in which he is located during an operation.
Deinde proiice in Cancrum uncinos qui conueniunt ei.	Then cast in cancer hooks that belong to him.
Postea concaua ipsum ab omni parte cum cute, secundum perscrutationem, donec non remaneat aliquid ex radicibus eius: et dimitte sanguinem currere, et non abscindas ipsum uelociter, imo exprime loca, et absterge sanguinem grossum totum manu tua, aut cum quo possibile est ibi ex instrumentis.	Then close up the whole part of it with ointment after a scrutiny, until no part remains of its roots: and let blood flow, and do not sever it quickly, but express the places, and wipe away the grosser blood entirely by hand or with whatever means is possible at the place.
Si autem contrarietatem facit tibi fluxus sanguinis grossi ex incisione arteriae, aut uenae: tunc cauteriza uenam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	But if it makes you contrary by flowing gross blood from an incision of an artery or a vein: then causticate a vein until the blood is severed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then, the care for himself with the other cure, until he is healed.
¶ De cura Hydropisis.	§ On the treatment of hydrops.
Caput LIIII.	Head XLIV.
Iam narrauimus in diuisione species Hydropisis, et qualiter fit aggregatio aquae: et signa omnis speciei, et curationem eius cum medicinis.	I have already spoken at length about the different types of hydrops and how water is concentrated: the signs of each type, and its treatment with medicines.
Et illa quae curatur cum ferro, non est nisi species asclitis sola: et non approximatur cum ferro speciei timpanitis: neque speciei hyposarcae penitus: nam illud mortale est.	And those that are cured by iron, there is no need to add any explanation about the type of hydrops: and it does not come close to the iron for the case of ear-droops: nor for the case of low-salty body (hyposality): for this is a deadly thing.
Quando tu iam medicatus es hanc speciem Hydropisis timpanitis cum medicinis, et non contulit medicatio tua: tunc considera.	When you have already treated the ear-droops with these medicines and your treatment has not been successful: then reflect.
Nam si infirmo iam consecuta est debilitas, aut est cum eo infirmitas alia praeter Hydropisim: sicut si sit cum eo tussis, aut uentris solutio, et similia illis: tunc caue ne mediceris ei cum ferro: quoniam est timor illud.	For if the person is already weak or there is another infirmity besides hydrops: such as if he has a cough, or a watery urine, and things like that: then be careful not to treat him with iron: for there is a fear of that.
Si autem uides infirmum exuberantis uirtutis, neque est cum eo aegritudo praeter Hydropisim solam: et non est puer, neque senex: tunc modus operationis in eo est, ut tu eleues infirmum stantem inter manus tuas, et minister post ipsum exprimat uentrem eius manu sua impellendo aquam ad inferiorem partem pectinis.	But if you see a person with an exuberant vigor, and there is no other disease besides hydrops: and he is not a boy or an old man: then the mode of treatment in him is, so that you stand between his hands and have him express his breath with his hand, driving the water to the lower part of the pineal.
