Then I attempted again, and detected on the bone above the first detection: and I found a continuous corruption with the bone, and sharpened what seemed right to me from that corruption as well.
Deinde conatus sum restaurationem eius.	Then I tried to repair it.
Et non est restauratum.	And it was not restored.
Detexi ergo super ipsum iterum, et non cessaui incidere os particulatim, et conari restaurationem eius: et non est restauratum, donec incidi ex osse circiter palmum unum, et extraxi illud cum medulla sua.	Then I detected on the same thing again, and did not cease to pierce the bone in detail, and tried to repair it: and it was not repaired until I pierced from the bone a little palm, and took that out with its marrow.
Deinde restauraui ipsum cum medicinis, et consolidatum est uelociter, et sanatum: et non fuit necessaria haec iteratio in operatione eius, et sectione ipsius, nisi propter dispositionem debilitatis infirmi, et paucitatem tolerantiae eius, et timorem meum super ipsum de morte: quoniam accidebat ei in omnibus horis ex superfluitate euacuationis syncopis mala.	Then I repaired it with medicines, and it was quickly consolidated, and healed: and this iteration in the operation of it, and its cutting, would not have been necessary except for the weakness of the nurse, and her lack of tolerance, and my fear over it from death: because it happened to him at all times from the bad syncope of discharge.
Sanatus est ergo sanatione integra: et nata est in loco ossis caro dura, et bona facta est dispositio in corpore suo, et rediit uirtus eius: et conuersatus est in dispositionibus suis: et non fecit ei contrarietatem in ambulatione nocumentum omnino.	He was therefore healed with a whole healing: and flesh grew in the place of the bone, and a good disposition came to his body, and his strength returned: and he recovered in his dispositions: and he did not feel any opposition when walking at all.
Si autem os eminens in loco corporis iam fractum est: tunc oportet ut serres ipsum, secundum hunc modum: et est: ut accipias ligamentum, et stringe ipsum in extremitate ossis eminentis: et praecipe alicui, qui extendat ipsum ad sursum: et pone ligamentum aliud ex lana grossius ligamento primo.	But if the jaw is突出 and already broken: then one should bind it up, in this way: that you take a ligament, and tie it firmly at the end of the prominent bone: and instruct someone who will hold it upwards: and put another ligament, from a thicker wool, on the first ligature.
Deinde liga ipsum super carne, quae est suh osse: et extende extremitatem eius, ut trahas carnem ad inferiora: et tu detegis carnem super locum quem uis serrare, ut non laedat Serra carnem.	Then bind the flesh up over the bone which is on either side of the jaw: and extend its end so that you can pull the flesh downward: and you shall cover the flesh over the place which you wish to bind, so as not to cut the flesh with the saw.
Pone lignum, aut tabulam sub osse inferius decenter: quoniam quando facis illud, non prohibetur quin secet carnem corruptam.	Place a board or board below the bone on either side: for when you do this, it is not forbidden to cut the corrupt flesh.
Et oportet ut sit Serratura super locum corruptum parumper, ut non sit in concauitate ossis corruptio: et non appareat in apparitione sua sensui, et cogat ad Serraturam sui uice alia.	And it should be that the binding is a little over the corrupted place, so as not to appear on the appearance of the bone; and does not appeal to its own force, but forces itself with the force of another binding.
Quod si os est corruptum, et non est eminens, imo continuatur pars eius cum parte: et corruptio est in medio eius, aut in parte ipsius: tunc detege carnem ab omnibus partibus totam.	If the bone is corrupted and not prominent, then a portion of it remains with another part: corruption is in its middle or in some part of it; then you shall cover all the flesh from every part.
Deinde pone lignum inferius.	Then place the board below.
Postea serra illud ex parte prima, ubi est corruptio, donec continuetur Serratura ex parte altera: et sit Serratura secundum longitudinem a corruptione parumper, secundum quod diximus.	Then bind that first part from which the corruption proceeds, until it continues to be bound on the other side; and let the binding be of about the same length from corruption as we said above.
Quod si corruptio est in iunctura, incide ipsam iuncturam corruptam, et serra os ubi continuatur ex parte altera.	If the corruption is in the joint, then cut that joint which is corrupted, and bind the bone where it continues on the other side.
Si uero corruptio est in continuatione duarum iuncturarum, tunc non est in ea ingenium nisi abrasio.	But if the corruption is in the continuation of two joints, then there is nothing of genius in that; there is only an injury.
Quod si corruptio est in pectine manus, aut in pectine pedis: tunc res in eo est difficilis ualde.	If the corruption is in the hand or foot shaft: then the matter is very difficult.
Verum oportet, ut inquiras corruptionem qualiter appareat tibi.	But you should inquire how the corruption appears to you.
Et abradas eam, et mundes ipsam secundum quamcunque dispositionem tibi possibile est, et cum quocunque ingenio rectificatur tibi: quando non facit tibi contrarietatem Vena, aut Neruus.	And cut it and clean it up according to whatever arrangement you can make, and with whatever genius it rectifies itself to you: when it does not do you any harm by cutting the vein or nerve.
Et scias quod incisoria, et Serrae ad incidendum ista ossa sunt multa, secundum situm ossium, et praparationem eorum, et ipsorum grossitudinem, et subtilitatem eorum, et magnitudinem, et paruitatem ipsorum, et duriciem ipsorum, et eorum raritatem.	And you shall know that the incisor and serrated saws are many for cutting these bones, according to the position of the bones, and their preparation, and their thickness and subtlety and magnitude and perfection and hardness and their rarity.
Quapropter oportet, ut praepares omni speciei operationis instrumentum conueniens ad illam operationem.	Therefore, it is necessary that you prepare an instrument suitable for each kind of operation.
Et scias, quod operationes istae significant tibi super speciem instrumenti quo indiges, quando tecum est studium longum.	And you shall know, these operations require a long study on the instrument with which you work.
Et cognitio modorum huius artis, testimonium modorum aegritudinum: tunc enim iam inuenies per teipsum illud quod conuenit ei ex instrumentis ad omnem infirmitatem.	And the knowledge of these ways will be a testimony to your understanding of the manner of sickness; for then you will already have found through yourself that which suits him from among the instruments for every illness.
Et ego sum firmans tibi in ultimo huius capituli numerum instrumentorum, quae pones exempla super quae incides, et probationem qua experiaris super alia.	And I am confirming to you, at the end of this chapter, the number of instruments which you place as examples on which you operate, and which you have tried out on other patients.
Forma Serrae.	The form of the saw.
Forma alterius Serrae.	The form of another saw.
Forma Serrae alterius.	The form of a third saw.
Forma Serrae alterius.	The form of a fourth saw.
Haec forma Serrae depicta, sit decenter facta.	This drawing of the form of the saw, as it has been made somewhat off-center.
Fiat arcus eius superior, acuitas eius ex ferro: et manubrium eius ex buxo, et sit pyramidale decenter factum.	Let the curve of its upper part be made of iron; and the handle, of boxwood; and let it be made with a slightly off-center pyramid.
Forma Rasorii iuncturarum.	The form of the razors joined together.
Sit caput huius Rasorii, secundum formam capitis claui stellati: et puncta eius sint secundum formam punctorum elischetfegi.	Let the head of this razor be shaped like a star-shaped clavulus; and its points be shaped like the points of an אלישטפיגי (elishtefigi).
Et non conuenit, nisi ut fricentur cum eo capita iuncturarum, quando corrumpuntur, aut os amplum, et magnum est.	And it does not fit, unless it rubs with the head of joined razors when it is worn; for it has a large and broad lip.
Forma maioris Rasorii.	The form of the larger razor.
Forma medii Rasorii.	The form of the middle-sized razor.
Forma Rasorii lati.	The form of the wide razor.
Forma Rasorii in quo est concauitas.	The form of the razor in which is a concave curve.
Forma Rasorii alterius subtilis.	The form of another thin razor.
Forma Rasorii alterius curuatae extremitatis.	The form of the razor with its curved extreme end.
Forma Rasorii parui, subtilis tentae.	The form of a small, thin razor for the tip of the finger.
Forma Rasorii cum quo inciduntur ossa.	The form of the razor used for cutting bones.
Forma etiam Rasorii magni.	Form also rasors great.
Hoc similatur Radio, et extremitas est sicut Serra: exhibetur in locis multis ex rasione ossium.	This is similar to a chisel and its edge is like a saw: it is displayed in many places from the chiseling of bones.
Forma Rasorii quod conuenit ad rasionem eius quod perforatum est ex ossibus.	Form of the chisel which is suitable for its chiseling that which is pierced out from the bones.
Extremitas eius triangula, acutarum est extremitatum.	Its edge is triangular, its extremes are acute.
Fit ex Indi.	Fit from India.
Et similiter oportet, ut fiant omnia quae diximus ex Rasoriis, et Incisoriis, et Serris.	And likewise it is necessary that all which we have said of the chisel, and of the chisel, and of the saw.
¶ De incisione extremitatum, et Serratura ossium.	Of incisions extremes, and sawing bones.
Caput LXXXIX.	Head LXXXIX.
Putrefiunt extremitates, aut ex caussa extrinseca, aut intrinseca.	The extremes putrefy, or for an extrinsic cause, or an intrinsic one.
Cum ergo medicatus fueris illam corruptionem curatione medicinarum, et non confert curatio: et uides corruptionem incidere in membrum, quam non repercutit aliquid: tunc oportet ut incidas illud membrum usque ubi consequitu corruptio, ut euadat infirmus per illud a morte, aut a malicia quae est maior defectu membri.	When therefore the patient was cured by the cure of medicines, and does not confer the cure: and you see corruption to affect a member, which does not recur any injury: then it is necessary that you should cut off that part where the consequences of corruption, so the sick one may be taken away from death, or from the malice which is greater defect of member.
Et signum cui accidit illud est, quod denigratur membrum, donec putetur: quod ignis combussit ipsum, aut putrefit post nigredinem: donec inciditur illa putredo usque ad illud quod sequitur illud membrum, et serpit in totum corpus.	And the sign which has happened to that is, that the member is disgraced, until it is cured: that fire has burned it itself, or has putrefied after its color: until that corruption has affected that part, which follows that member, and creeps into all the body.
Propera ergo cum incisione eius, et similiter si caussa corruptionis est a percussione quorundam uenenosorum: sicut scorpionis marini, et uiperae, et rutellae, et similium.	Therefore, with incisions, and likewise if the cause of corruption is from percussion of some venenosos: such as scorpioni sea, and vipers, and weasels, and similar ones.
Si ergo corruptio, aut percussio est in extremitate digiti, tunc incide digitum, et non des spacium corruptioni, ut incedat usque ad reliquam manum.	If therefore corruption, or percussion is in the extreme of a finger, then cut off the finger, and not leave any space for corruption, so that it may affect to the remaining hand.
Et similiter si accidit in manu, tunc incide eam ex radice focilis, et non des spacium corruptioni, donec capiat in focili brachii.	And likewise if has happened in the hand, then cut off it from the root of a chisel, and not leave any space for corruption, until it takes up to the chisel of the forearm.
Et si inuadit in eo, tunc incide brachium apud cubitum in iunctura sua.	And if it has penetrated into it, then cut off the forearm at the elbow joint.
Si autem pertransit corruptio, et uides eum circiter cubitum: tunc in illo est mors infirmi.	But if corruption has passed over it, and you see that it is swollen around the hip: then in that is death by the nurse.
Et administrare praeter illud ex curatione, est quantitas uirtus.	And to administer apart from that cure, is the quantity of virtue.
Et similiter fac de pede, quando inuadit corruptio in digito, tunc incide ipsum apud unum nodorum: et si capit in pectine pedis, tunc incide pedem totum.	And likewise do with the foot, when corruption appears in the toe, then cut it at the root of a knot: and if it enters into the shin, then cut the whole foot.
Si autem ascendit ad genu, tunc incide crus apud iuncturam genu.	But if it ascends up to the knee, then cut the leg at the joint of the knee.
Quod si corruptio iam peruenit supra genu, tunc non est in ea ingenium, nisi dimissio, et relinquere infirmum morti.	That which if corruption has already reached above the knee, then there is no art in it, except cutting off, and leave the sick to death.
Et modus incidendi membrum, aut serrandi ipsum est, ut stringas ligamentum in inferiori, quem uis incidere: et stringe ligamentum aliud supra locum.	And the mode of incising a limb, or of stretching it out, is that you should tie the ligament below, which you would cut: and tie another ligament above the place.
Et extendat minister ligamentum unum ad inferiora: et extendat minister aliud ligamentum superius ad sursum.	And extend one minister of a ligament to the lower: and extend another minister of a ligament upwards to the top.
Et tu separa carnem quae est inter duo ligamenta, cum Spatumili lato, donec detegatur caro tota.	And thou shalt separate the flesh which is between these two ligaments, with a broad chisel, until thou shalt discover all the bone.
Deinde incidatur, aut serretur.	Then cut it, or stretch it out.
Et oportet, ut ponas ab omnibus partibus pannum lini, et non tangat Serra locum sanum: et accidat infirmo laesio addita, et apostema calidum.	And it is necessary that you should put a cloth of linen between all the parts, and let not the chisel touch the sound place: and cut to the sick with added woe, and let not be cold poultice.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis interius dum operaris, tunc cauteriza locum uelociter: aut pone super ipsum quosdam pulueres abscindentes sanguinem.	But if there should happen to flow the blood inward while you work, then cauterize the place quickly: or put on it some powder that binds the blood.
Deinde redi ad medicationem tuam, donec compleatur.	Then return to your own medicating, until it is complete.
Deinde liga membrum uulneratum cum ligamento conueniente ei, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then bind the wounded limb with a fitting ligament, and take care of it, until it heals.
Et ego narro tibi quod accidit uiro in pede suo, hoc idem accidens quod narro tibi.	And I tell you what happened to the man in his foot, this same thing that I tell you.
Quod est, quia accidit in pede suo nigredo, cum adustione quae assimilatur combustioni ignis: et corruptio illa in primis accidit in digito suo, donec coepit pedem totum.	That is, because it happened to the man in his black foot, when it was scorched like the fire of burning: and that corruption first began in his toe, until it came into the whole foot.
Properauit ergo uir ex seipso, postquam uidit corruptionem incidere in membro cum uehementia eius, quod inuenit ex dolore, et adustione eius: et incidit ipsum apud iuncturam, et sanatus est.	The wound was found to be well after he saw the corruption enter into a limb with its movement, which he discovered from pain and its heat; and it struck him at the joint, and was healed.
Et postquam praeteriit ei tempus longum, accidit ei illa eadem corruptio in digito manus suae indice.	And after a long time had passed, that corruption again occurred to him in the same way in the index finger of his hand.
Venit ergo ad me, et conatus sum recuperare illam superfluitatem cum eo quod posui super manum ex medicinis post mundificationem corporis eius: et non repercussa est superfluitas, et coepit incedere in digitum alium: donec coepit coruptio in manum.	Then he came to me, and I tried to restore that excess with him when I put on his hand from the medicines after purifying his body: and the excess did not recur, and it began to hurt in another finger: until the corruption began to enter into a hand.
Vocauit ergo me, ad incidendum manum eius: et nolui illud, sperans ex me super repercussionem illius superfluitatis: et timui etiam super ipsum apud incisionem manus eius mortem.	He called on me to cut off his hand: and I would not do it, hoping from myself regarding the recurrence of that excess: and I was afraid even for himself regarding the death of his hand at the cutting.
Quoniam uirtus uiri erat super casum.	For the strength of the arm was above the loss.
Postquam ergo desperauit de me, reuersus est ad terram suam: et peruenit ad me de eo, quia properauit, et incidit manum suam totam: et sanatus est.	Afterwards he was disappointed about me, and turned to his own land; and he came back to me on the subject, for he wished it well, and struck off his whole hand; and he was healed.
Et non attuli hanc narrationem, nisi ut sit adiutorium super illud quod cadit de genere huius aegritudinis: et ut sit significatio qua significetur, et secundum quam agatur.	And I did not bring this account unless it be an aid to that which falls regarding this kind of disease: and to show what it means, and according as it is applied.
¶ De cura Sinuum, et qualitate clisterizationis cum medicinis.	On the treatment of gangrene, and on the quality of cauterisation with medicines.
Caput XC.	Chapter 80.
Quando accidit apostema in quibusdam membris carnosis, et prolongatur spacium apostematis, donec collectionem facit saniei: deinde rumpitur, aut perforatur, et egreditur quod in eo est ex sanie, et remanet locus uacuus quasi sit uas: et cutis quae est super ipsum sicut pannus qui iam subtiliatus est: et non peruenit ad ultimum in corruptione sua, neque imprimit in os, neque in neruum, neque in ligamentum: meretur ut nominetur Sinus: et non nominatur Fistula: uerumtamen si prolongatur spacium eius, donec imprimat corruptio in aliquid horum membrorum, tunc nominatur Fistula, aut zuken.	When gangrene occurs in some fleshy limb, and space is prolonged for the poultice, until it draws together: then it bursts, or pierces, and that which is in it comes out, leaving a hollow place like a wound: and the skin over it looks like thin cloth: and does not spread to the extreme of corruption, neither does it enter into the mouth, the nose, or the ligaments: it deserves to be called Sinus: but does not bear the name Fistula: however, if it is prolonged in space, until it impresses corruption in some of these limbs, then it is called Fistula, or a bore.
Et cura eius est, ut incidas illam cutem totam sicut reuoluitur: et praecipue quando subtiliata est, et facta sicut pannus: et confidis quia non aaehaeret cum loco, propter corruptionem suam.	And the cure is, that you should strike off that skin all at once like a garment; and especially when it has been thinned and made like a cloth; and trust that it will not adhere to the place on account of its decay.
Si autem speras quod adhaereat cutis, et non consequitur ex eo corruptio illa ultima consecutione: et si in cute est spissitudo ex carne, tunc cura ipsum cum Clisteri: et est, ut consideres ad Sinum.	But if you expect that the skin will adhere and that that corruption will not follow from it in the end: and if there is a thickness of flesh in the skin, then cure it with myrrh: and this is what you should consider as regard the sinews.
Tunc si est magnus, et pus quod emittitur ex eo est foetidi odoris: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum medicamine aegyptio, quod est aceti, et olei, et ziniar, partes recipiens aequales, aggregentur in uase: et decoquantur super ignem, donec rubeat medicamen: et ueniat in spissitudinem mellis.	Then if it is large, and the pus that issues from it is very foul: then prepare it with the Egyptian medicine, which is vinegar, oil, and resin, parts in equal quantities, mixed together in a vessel; and let it boil over fire until the medicine turns red: and let it come to be of the consistence of honey.
Deinde accipe ex eo quod tibi necesse est: et dissolue ipsum cum aqua et melle, et clisteriza cum eo Sinum: et stringe orificium eius, et dimitte medicinam in eo ad quantitatem duarum horarum.	Then take from it what you need: and dissolve it with water and honey, and prepare it with the myrrh, and string the opening of it, and let the medicine enter into it to the quantity of two hours' duration.
Deinde extrahe ipsum cum expressione: fac illud diebus tot, donec mundificetur Sinus, et remoueatur foetor.	Then extract that medicine with the expression; let it be for several days, until the sinews are clean and the smell is gone.
Et quandoque clisterizatur cum aqua cineris, quando non est tibi praesens hoc medicamen: et est, ut accipias cinerem lignorum uitis, aut cinerem ex lignis ilicis: et proiicias super eam aquam.	And when you prepare it with water of ash, when this medicine is not present with you: and this is what you should do, that you take the ash of oak or of elm-wood: and pour it on the water.
Deinde cola eam, et clisteriza cum ea, donec confidas quod Sinus iam ablutus est.	Then stir it, and prepare it with the myrrh, until you are certain that the sinews are clean.
Quod si infirmo non est tolerantia super medicamen aegyptium, neque aquam cineris, tunc clisteriza ipsum cum aqua et melle, cui iam permixtum est aliquid ex ziniar contrito.	If the patient is not tolerant of the Egyptian medicine or water of ash, then prepare it with water and honey, to which has been added a little crushed resin.
Aut clisteriza ipsum cum melle et uino permixtis, quoniam de proprietate mellis est, ut mundificet, et abluat: et uinum facit adhaerere Sinum, praecipue quando in uino est superfluitas stipticitatis et siccitatis.	Or prepare it with honey and wine, because of the property of honey to clean and wash away: and the wine makes the sinews adhere, especially when there is an abundance of styptic and drying in the wine.
Cum facis illud aliquotiens, et confidis quod Sinus corruptio iam remota est: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum eo quod facit nasci carnem in eo.	How you do that sometimes, and trust that the corruption of the sin has already been removed: then wash him with water with what he does to give birth to flesh in it.
Et est, ut accipias ex emplastro dyafinicon: et dissoluas ipsum cum oleo rosato, et uino stiptico: aut clisteriza ipsum cum quibusdam medicinis, et unguentis aliis, quorum proprietates scripsi in tractatu unguentorum.	And is, so you get from an emplastro dyafinicon: and dissolve it with olive oil, and wine tonic: or wash him with some medicines, and other ointments, whose properties I have written in the treatise of ointments.
Quod si orificium Sinus est strictum, in quo non capit cannula clisteris: tunc amplifica ipsum cum ferro parumper: aut pone in ipso licinium inuolutum in unguento aegyptio, aut in unguento basilicon, donec amplificetur.	That if the orifice of the sinus is tight, in which the cannula of the clister does not enter: then increase it with a little iron: or put in it licorium soaked in ointment Egyptian, or in basilicon ointment, until it increases.
Et similiter si est orificium etiam amplum, tunc aggrega labia eius cum sutura: et dimitte ex eo quantitatem in quam ingrediatur clistere sine additione.	And similarly if the orifice is also wide, then add the lips with a stitch: and let go from it the amount that is mixed with the clister without adding anything to it.
Et similiter si orificium eius ex quo currit pus, est eleuatum ad superiora: tunc seca ipsum in depressiori loco qui est in ipso, ut currat ex eo pus usque inferius: quoniam pus quando coartatur in profunditate Sinus, prohibet carnem generari in eo.	And similarly if the orifice from which the pus runs is raised upward: then dry it up in a lower place that is in it, so that the pus runs out of it downwardly: for when the pus is constricted in the depth of the sinus, it prevents flesh from being born in it.
Quod si non est tibi possibile secare Sinum circiter inferius eius secundum quod uis: tunc conare, ut praepares membrum praeparatione qua currat ex eo pus cum facilitate secundum quod praeparatur tibi.	That if it is not possible for you to dry the sinus completely around its lower part according to what you want: then try, so that you prepare the member with a preparation that runs out of it with ease according to which it is prepared for you.
Conare, ut non retineatur in eo aliquid ex pus omnino: et accipe medicinas consolidatiuas quae ponuntur super signum, conuenientes ad illud quod uis.	Try, so that nothing of the pus is retained in it at all: and take medicines that are put on a sign, suitable to that which you want.
Et extende eas super pannum lini.	And spread them out over the cloth of linen.
Et sit pannus tantae quantitatis, qua fiat communicatio totius Sinus.	And let the cloth be of such a quantity that it communicates with all the sinus.
Deinde incide cum forficibus in directo orificii Sinus foramen, amplius orificio Sinus parumper.	Then cut with forceps on the direct hole of the sinus orifice, a slightly larger hole.
Deinde extende ex unguentis lenibus super pannum alium, secundum quantitatem foraminis: et pone eum super ipsum positione longinqua ab orificio Sinus, ut alleuietur exitus pus ex eo: et non auferas pannum magnum, nisi post dies aliquos uice una.	Then spread from the ointment soft on another cloth, according to the quantity of the hole: and put it on him in a distant position from the sinus orifice, so that the exit of pus from it is facilitated: and do not take off the large cloth, until after some days a piece.
Ille autem qui est super orificium Sinus, est ille quem remoues in omni hora, ut egrediatur quod aggregatur in eo ex pus: et ut scias, an illud quod currit ex eo uirus, est multum, aut parum: aut digestum, aut indigestum.	And yet who is above the orifice of the sinus, is he whom you stir at all times, that he may go out what has gathered in him from pus: and know that, for this which runs out of it virus, is much, or little: or digested, or indigested.
Et cum hoc iterum considera locum Sinus ipsius, an in ipso sentiat dominus eius dolorem, aut non sit in eo dolor, et an sit in eo apostema, aut non sit in eo apostema.	And when you consider this place again of the sinus itself, does the lord feel pain in it, or is there no pain in it? And does he feel a plug in it, or not?
Cum ergo protenditur medicatio tua taliter, et uides materiam quae egreditur super orificium Sinus, tunc scias, quod Sinus iam adhaeret, aut approximat adhaerentiae: tunc ergo solue ipsum in mane, aut in tertio die: et quando soluis uulnus, tunc permuta pannum alium, et renoua unguentum.	So when your medication extends thus far, and you see the material that has come out above the sinus orifice, then know that the sinus is now fastening itself, or approaching the fastening: so then dissolve it in the morning, or on the third day: and when you dissolve the wound, then change the cloth to another, and renew the ointment.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post spacium longum uirus subtile, tunc non desperes de adhaerentia eius, nam sanatio eius appropinquat, quoniam ex hominibus sunt qui tardant generationem carnis in uulneribus suis, et ex eis sunt qui agunt econtrario illius.	But if the virus comes out of the sinus after a long space, do not despair concerning its fastening, for the healing of it approaches, because there are people who delay the generation of flesh in their wounds, and from them there are who act in the contrary way.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post dies multos pus indigestum, tunc scias quod sinus non adhaeret.	But if it comes out after many days of pus that is not digested, then know that the sinus does not fasten itself.
Si ergo tardatur adhaerentia Sinus, et prolongatur res eius: tunc adde in exiccatione medicinarum, uerum faciant medici, ut sint medicinae in substantia sua humidae, et in uirtute sua siccae: sicut unguentum dyafinicon, quando additur in eo superfluitas additionis ex zegi.	But if the fastening of the sinus is delayed, and its duration is prolonged: then add to the drying up of medicines, truly let the doctors make them, so that they are in their substance moist, and in their virtue dry: just as the unguent of daphenicon, when added thereto of an excess of addition out of zеги.
Et ex magis ultimo quo curatur, est, ut accipias unguentum dyafinicon, et soluatur cum oleo rosato, et roretur super ipsum uinum antiquum aequale in substantia sua.	And from the greatest part also, when it is cured, it is, that you take the unguent of daphenicon, and dissolve it with oil of rose, and rub it on the old wound to an equal degree in its substance.
Deinde confice ipsum cum eo, et utere ipso.	Then put on the ointment with it, and use it.
Et iam facit simile huic actioni, quando non est tibi praesens unguentum dyafinicon, mel, quando decoquis ipsum, donec ingrossetur, et uteris eo.	And this same action does this to you, when the unguent of daphenicon is not present with you, when you heat it up, until it thickens, and you use it.
Aut accipe myrrham, et aloen, et olibanum: tere totum, et pulueriza illud super mel dum est super ignem.	Take myrrh and aloe and olive oil; let it be thoroughly mixed with the dust, and spread over honey when it is still warm on fire.
Deinde line super ipsum pannum, et stringe ipsum super Sinum: et line cum melle quod decoquisti, donec ingrossatum est: et pulueriza super ipsum species, et pone super ipsum pannum, et stringe eum.	Then wrap a cloth over the wound and tie it tightly around the سین; and cover with honey what you have made to be a poultice, until it has thickened: and apply the dust on the wound, and wrap it again in the cloth, and tie it tightly.
Et quandoque administratur in illo aristolochia longa, et radices lilii coelestis, et est lilium: et farina herbi, et centaurea.	And when you have administered to him long-stemmed aristaeus, and the roots of sky-lily, and it is a lily; and grass-root, and daisy.
Utere eis simplicibus, aut aggregatis, tere ea, et cribella ipsa: et pulueriza super mel quod narraui, et utere eo.	Use them simple, or gathered, as they are, and the sifting of themselves: and apply the dust on honey which you have poured out, and use it.
Quod si prolongatur res Sinus, et non sanatur hac curatione: tunc scias, quod in profundo eius est corruptio: aut iam facit impressionem in ossibus, aut in reliquis membris duris, aut ligamentis: tunc cura ipsum curatione Fistularum, secundum quod praemissum est.	That if the disease of the Sinus is prolonged, and does not heal by this cure: then you shall know that there is corruption in his depths; or it begins to make an impression on bones, or on other hard members of the body, or on ligaments: then you should resort to the cure of Fistulas, as has been aforesaid.
¶ De cura Panaritii et unguis attritae, et incisione digiti additi, et sectione.	Of the cure of the finger with a panaritis, and of an rubbed nail, and of incision of the finger, added with section.
Caput XCI.	Chapter LXI
Panaritium est apostema quod nascitur sub ungue pollicis manus, aut pedis: et fortasse nascitur in reliquis digitis.	Panaritis is a swelling that arises under the nail of the thumb or of any other finger, and perhaps it may arise in the other fingers also.
Cum ergo prolongatur res eius, et negligitur curato eius, et apostematur apostemate calido: aut corrumpitur, et emittit pus, donec corrodit radicem unguis: et fortasse corrumpit eam totam, et fortasse peruenit corruptio ad os, donec est ei odor foetidus: et fit extremitas digiti lata, et fit color eius fuscus.	When then the disease of this has been prolonged, and the cure of it has been neglected, and has become a sore with a warm moisture; or it is corrupted, and discharges pus, until it corrodes the nail's root: and perhaps it may be corrupted altogether, and perhaps it may reach the mouth, until it has an odour unclean: and makes the end of the finger large, and makes its color dark.
Quando ergo tu curas ipsum, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio tua: tunc oportet ut incidas cum ferro totam superfluitatem quae remansit ex ungue.	When then you resort to the cure of it, with that which we have said in the division, and your cure does not bring relief: then you must cut off the whole superfluity that remains from the nail.
Deinde cauteriza uulnus post illud.	Then cauterize the nail after that.
Cauterium enim iuuatiuum est ualde.	Cauterium enim iuuatiuum est ualde.
Si uero os est sanum, et est unguis etiam sana, et additiones uacuae unguis iam comprimunt carnem ad interiora, et incipiunt pungere ipsam, et laedunt eam: tunc oportet ut ponas Radium subtilem sub angulo unguis quae pungit carnem, et impelle eam sursum: et incide eam carnem cum facilitate, et pone super illud quod remanet de carne ex medicinis comburentibus, corrosiuis, donec remoueatur totum eius.	For if the bone is healthy and the nail also, and the nails too tight to the flesh within, and it begins to hurt: then you should put a small amount of radium under the angle of the nail that hurts the flesh, and press it upwards: and cut the flesh easily, and place on top of what remains of the flesh from burning medicines, rusts until it is completely moved away.
Deinde cura illud cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then care for that with the nail, until it heals.
Si autem corruptio iam imprimit in os, tunc oportet ut incidas illud os, et extrahas ipsum: non enim sanatur unquam dum permanet in eo os corruptum.	If, however, the corruption has already begun to press on the bone, then you should cut that bone out and remove it: for it never heals while it remains in it.
Quod si uides corrosionem et corruptionem incedere in digitum, tunc incide eum in uno nodorum, secundum quod praemissa est eius rememoratio.	If you see the corruption and the rust entering into a finger, then cut it at one of its joints, according to what has been said above about its reminder.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for that injury, until it heals.
Si autem accidat ungui attritio, aut percussio: et contingit in ea dolor uehemens, tunc oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	If, however, the nail has been worn away or hit: and there is a very painful pain in it, then you should let blood from it first.
Deinde seca unguem cum Spatumili acuto sectione transuersa de sursum ad uisum.	Then dry the nail with a sharp spatulium across from above to the tip.
Et custodi, ne sectio perueniat ad carnem quae est sub ungue, nam tu facies accidere per illud super infirmum dolorem uehementem, et erit caussa ad natiuitatem carnis additae in loco.	And guard it, so that the cut does not go into the flesh below the nail, for you would cause a very painful pain to arise on the sick person, and it would be a cause of the birth of flesh added in place.
Deinde cura locum cum eo quod sedat dolores.	Then care for that place with the seat that causes pains.
Digitus uero additus qui nascitur in quibusdam manibus hominum, fortasse est carnosus totus: et fortasse sunt in quibusdam eorum ossa, et fortasse est in eo unguis: et quidam eorum nascitur in radice iuncturae, aut est natiuitas eius in quibusdam nodis digiti.	The finger, however, added which is born in some hands of men, perhaps is fleshy all over: and perhaps there are bones in some of them, and perhaps there is a nail in it: and the birth of some of its joints or knuckles may be in the joint of the ligature, or in some of the joints of the finger.
Ille ergo qui nascitur in quibusdam nodis digiti, non mouetur: et ille qui nascitur apud iuncturam digiti, fortasse mouetur.	So then who is born in some joints of the finger does not move: and who is born at the knuckle of the finger, perhaps moves.
Eius ergo qui ex eis est carnosus, sectio eius facilis est.	Therefore he who has this fleshly part, the incision into him is easy.
Quod est, ut incidas ipsum apud radicem suam cum Spatumili lato.	Which is, that you may incise him at his root with a spatula-shaped blade.
Eius autem cuius natiuitas est in radice iuncturae curatio, est difficilis.	But of him whose birth is in the root of the joint, the cure is difficult.
Abstine ergo ab incisione eius.	Therefore abstain from incising him.
In illo uero qui nascitur in digito apud ultimum nodorum, tunc oportet ut incidas in primis carnem eius incisione rotunda usque ad os.	But in that one who is born in the digit at the last of the joints, then you should incise him in the first flesh round up to the mouth.
Deinde serra os cum una illarum Serrarum conuenientium ad illud.	Then close the mouth with one of those blades that are convenient for closing it.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for him, until he is healed.
Consolidatio autem quae accidit digitis adinuicem, multotiens accidit aut ex natiuitate hominis, id est, nascitur cum eo, aut a consolidatione uulneris, aut combustione ignis, et similibus.	But the consolidation that happens in the digits back to back, often occurs or from the birth of man, namely, he is born with it, or from the consolidation of the wound, or from the burning of fire, and similar things.
Oportet ergo ut seces illam consolidationem, donec redeant digiti secundum formam suam naturalem.	Therefore it should be that you separate this consolidation, until the digits return to their natural shape.
Deinde pone inter eos licinia, aut pannos infusos in oleo rosato: ut non consolidentur uelociter, et separa inter eos: aut pone inter eos laminam plumbi subtilem, donec consolidetur locus secundum quod oportet.	Then place between them a twig, or rags soaked in rose oil: so that they do not heal quickly, and separate them: or place between them a thin lead plate, until the site heals as it should.
Et similiter si accidat consolidatio quibusdam digitis cum palma, tunc seca illam consolidationem, secundum quod praeparatur et conuenit figurae membri.	And likewise if there is consolidation in some digits with the palm, then dry that consolidation, according to which it is prepared and convenient for the shape of the limb.
¶ De incisione Vitium.	The Vice of Incision:
Caput XCII.	Head LXXII.
Uites sunt Venae inuolutae, grossae, plenae superfluitatibus melancholicis quae accidunt in pluribus membris corporis: et plurimum euentus earum est in cruribus, praecipue in cruribus iter agentium et laborantium, et portantium.	Veins that are swollen and full of melancholic fluid occur in many parts of the body: and many of them come to an end in the legs, especially in the legs of those who move about a lot, and those who carry burdens.
Oportet ergo ut administres excussionem corporis ex cholera nigra aliquotiens excussione forti.	Therefore it should be that you administer a strong discharge of the body from black cholera by some means of exhaling.
Deinde phlebotoma patientis eas basilicam.	Then take the patient's blood with a large bowl.
Curatio uero earum cum ferro, est secundum duos modos.	The cure of these veins with iron is according to two methods.
Vnus eorum est, ut secentur, et extrahatur sanguis niger.	One is, so that they are heated and the black blood is drawn out.
Et modus alter est, ut eleuetur Vena, et extrahatur tota.	The other way is that you should cut off the vein and take it out entirely.
Sectio uero eius est secundum hunc modum.	The dissection is done this way according to this method.
Embroca crus in primis cum aqua calida multum, donec resoluatur sanguis grossus faeculentus.	First, wrap the leg with hot water until the thick, foul blood dissolves.
Deinde stringe crus infirmi a superiori parte coxae eius, usque ad inferiorem partem genu cum uitta.	Then tighten the tourniquet on the leg from the top of the hip to the bottom of the knee while it is bandaged.
Deinde seca uenam in loco uno, aut duobus, aut tribus sectione ampla.	Then dry off one, two, or three wide sections of the vein.
Deinde eleua, id est, extrahe sanguinem in manu tua ab inferiori parte cruris, usque ad sursum, et a superiori oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	Then cut off, that is to say, extract the blood in your hand from the lower part of the leg up to the top, and from the upper part it should be taken by the phlebotomist before it becomes weak.
Deinde seca unguem cum usque inferius: donec egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uides sufficere, et quam tolerat uirtus infirmi.	Then dry off the nail down to the bottom: until you see enough blood come out and how much strength the vein has left.
Postea liga eam: et praecipe ei, ut abstineat a cibis generantibus choleram nigram: et itera euacuationem et phlebotomiam, quando implentur Venae, et nocet illud infirmo.	Then tie it up: and tell him to refrain from foods that cause black cholesterol: and repeatedly drain and bleed the vein when they are full, and if it hurts the sick person.
Eleuatio autem eius est secundum hunc modum.	The elevation is done this way according to this method.
Rade crus infirmi, si in ea sunt pili multi.	Rub the leg with a hard object if there are many hairs in it.
Deinde intromitte ipsum in balneum: aut embroca ipsum in crure eius cum aqua calida, donec rubeat, et exuberentur Venae: aut exercitetur exercitio forti, si non est ei praesens balneum, donec calefiat membrum.	Then put the leg into a bath: or wrap it with hot water in the leg, until it reddens and the veins swell: or exercise it strongly if there is no bath present, until it warms up.
Deinde seca cutem in directo uenae sectione per longitudinem: aut in ultimo eius apud genu, aut in inferiori parte eius apud calcaneum.	Then dry off the skin along the vein in length: or at the end of the leg near the knee, or at the bottom part near the heel.
Deinde aperi cutem cum uncinis, et excoria uenam ab omni parte, donec appareat sensui: et est apud apparitionem eius, quod uides eam rubeam ad nigredinem decliuem.	Then open the skin with a hook, and scrape off the vein from all parts until you feel it: and at its appearance, you will see it red to black in color.
Cum ergo uadit ex cute, uides eam albam quasi sit chorda.	When you have taken it out of the skin, you will see it white as a cord.
Deinde intromitte sub ea Radium, donec quando eleuatur et egreditur de cute: suspende eam cum uncino caeco, leni.	Then insert a hook under it, until it is fully extracted from the skin: hang it with a blind hook, soft.
Deinde seca sectionem aliam prope illam sectionem tribus digitis.	Then dry off another wide section next to that section with three fingers.
Deinde excoria cutem a superiori parte uenae, donec appareat.	Then peel off the wound from the upper part of the skin, until it appears.
Deinde eleua eam cum Radiis sicut fecisti, et suspende eam cum uncino alio, sicut fecisti in primis.	Then wash it with water as you have done, and hang it with a hook as you did at first.
Deinde seca sectionem aliam, aut sectiones plures, si indiges illo.	Then dry another piece of skin, or more pieces if you are able to do so.
Deinde eleua, et incide ipsam ultima sectione apud calcaneum.	Then wash it, and make the cut at the heel.
Deinde extrahe eam ad sectionem quae est supra eam.	Then remove it to the section that is above it.
Et fac illud, donec extrahas eam ex sectione quae est superior, uel altior sectionibus omnibus, donec quando egreditur tota: tunc incide eam.	And do this, until you remove it from the upper section; or with higher sections all around, until when it is completely out: then cut it off.
Si autem non obedit tibi ad extrahendum, et eleuandum: tunc intromitte acum cum filo forti duplo, et liga eam, et extrahe ipsam: aut intromitte sub ea Radium: et reuolue manum tuam ad omnem partem, donec egrediatur.	But if it does not obey you when you try to remove and wash it: then insert a sharp tool with a double edge, and tie it, and remove it; or insert beneath it a Ray of iron: and rotate your hand around all parts, until it is completely out.
Et caue, ne incidatur.	And be careful not to cut.
Nam si incidatur, fit difficile tibi eleuare eam ualde, et ingreditur super infirmum ex ea nocumentum.	For if it cuts, it is difficult for you to wash it well, and it enters into the wound that has become injured.
Cum ergo extraxeris eam totam: tunc pone super locum uulnerum lanam submersam in uino et oleo rosato, aut oleo: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	So then when you remove it all: then place it on a wound place that has been dipped in wine and oil, or oil only; and take care of the wound, until it heals.
Quod si Vitis est contracta, habens tortuositatem cui sit inuolutio ad partes, et non est sicut diximus secundum rectitudinem: tunc oportet ut findas super eam ad omnem partem tortuositatis eius, et loca inuolutionis ipsius.	Which if it is contracted, has a curvature to the sides that has an edge to the parts, and is not like what we said concerning the straightness: then you must find on all parts of its curvature, and the locations of its edge.
Deinde suspende eam cum uncinis, donec eleues eam totam: et caue apud sectionem tuam super eam ne incidas uenam, aut uulneres: nam difficile fiet super te eleuare, uel extrahere eam.	Then hang it with a hook until you have washed it all; and be careful when you cut into the section that is above it, or wound it up: for it will be difficult for you to wash it well on yourself, or remove it.
Conserua ergo prudentiam tuam.	So then keep your caution.
Forma Incidentis quo sanatur Vitis.	The shape of the wound when it heals.
Forma Vncini caeci.	The shape of the hook.
Non est ei curuitas sicut reliquis Vncinis, neque est acutae extremitatis, ut non uulneret uenam: et est grossae flectuositatis, lenis: quoniam si esset subtilis, incideret uenam subtilitate sua: imo sit ei superflua grossitudo, sicut diximus.	It is not a curvature like the other hook, nor does it have acute extremities, so as to not wound the skin; and it has a slow bend, soft: for if it were slight, it would cut the skin with its subtleness: but it has too much grossness, as we said.
De extractione Venae cruris.	On the extraction of veins from the leg.
Caput XCIII.	De extractione venae cruris.
Haec Vena generatur in cruribus in terris calidis, sicut Alizegi, et terra Arabum, et in terris aridis, calidis, paucae teneritatis, id est, in quibus non nascitur herba, neque arbor.	This vein is generated in the legs on warm ground, as in Al-Izzi's land and in Arab lands, and in dry, hot lands with little softness, that is, where grass does not grow nor do trees spring up.
Et fortasse generatur in locis aliis corporis praeter crura.	And perhaps it is generated in other parts of the body besides the legs.
Et generatio quidem eius est a putrefactione quae accidit sub cute, sicut accidunt intra corpora serpentes et uermes ascarides, et uermes generati inter cutem et carnem.	And its generation is from putrefaction which occurs under the skin, as it occurs within the bodies of snakes and worms and lice, and worms generated between the skin and flesh.
Et signum incaeptionis euentus huius Venae est, quod accidit in crure inflammatio uehemens.	And the sign of the beginning of this vein is a sharp inflammation in the leg.
Deinde uesicatur locus.	Then the spot becomes sore and swollen.
Deinde incipit Vena exire ex loco illius uesicationis, quasi sit radix plantae, aut animal.	Then the vein begins to emerge from the site of the swelling, as if it were the root of a plant or an animal.
Cum ergo apparet ex ea extremitas eius, tunc oportet ut inuoluas super ipsam frustum plumbi, cuius pondus sit ex drachma keil, usque ad drachmas II et noda ipsam: et dimitte plumbum suspensum ex crure.	When this end appears, then you should wrap a lead wire around it, whose weight shall be of a drachm and a half, to the nodule; and remove the lead wire from the leg.
Quotiens ergo egreditur ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, inuolue illud in plumbo, et noda illud.	Whenever it emerges anything from it towards the outside, wrap that too in the lead, and mark that.
Quod si prolongatur multum, tunc incide partem eius, et inuolue residuum.	If it should last a long time, then you shall cut a part of it, and wrap the remainder.
Et non incidas eam radicitus antequam egrediatur tota.	And you shall not cut its root before it has completely emerged.
Quoniam si incidis, contrahitur, et ingreditur in carnem: et facit accidere apostema, et putredinem in loco, et ulcus malum.	For if you should cut it, it will wither, and go into the flesh: and it will cause pustules to form, and putrefaction in the spot, and a bad ulcer.
Quapropter oportet, ut suauiter tractetur, et extrahatur paulatim, donec egrediatur ex ultimo sui, et non remaneat ex ea aliquid in corpore: et ex hac quidem Vena egreditur in quibusdam hominibus quod est in longitudine sua quinque palmorum et decem.	Therefore it should be handled gently, and extracted gradually, until it has completely emerged from its root, and there remains nothing of it within the body: and from this vein emerge some men, who are, according to its length, five hands and ten fingers long.
Et iam peruenit ad me, quia exiuit uiro ex XX palmis.	And now I have come to you, for it has reached the age of twenty years.
Si autem inciditur tibi in hora medicationis tuae: tunc intromitte radium in foramine eius, et perfora eam foramine longo, cum corpore, donec euacuetur totum quod est in ea ex materia: et administra putrefactionem loci cum medicinis diebus aliquot.	If, however, you should cut yourself in the course of your treatment: then you shall introduce a needle into its opening, and pierce it with a long needle, along with the body, until all that is in it is discharged from the matter: and administer the medicine of the place with remedies over several days.
Deinde cura ipsum curatione apostematum.	Then the care is with the cure of ulcers.
Et haec quidem Vena quandoque habet ramos multos, praecipue quando apparet in iunctura pedis, aut in pede ipso: et accidunt ei orificia multa, et egreditur ex omni orificio ramus.	And this indeed The vein has branches when it is many, especially when it appears in the joint of the foot, or in the foot itself: and many openings are found, and a branch goes out from every opening.
Cura ergo ipsam, sicut diximus in diuisione, et cum eo quod praemissum est.	Then the care of it, as we have said in the division, and with what precedes.
¶ De sectione super Vermes generatos sub cute, et dicitur Aegritudo bouina.	De the section on worms that are born under the skin, and it is called The trouble of the cow.
Caput XCIIII.	Head LXXIII.
Haec Aegritudo nominatur in quadam terra apud nos Aegritudo bouina: propterea, quia multotiens accidit bouibus, et est uermis paruus unus, qui nascitur inter cutem et carnem.	This trouble is called in some place with us The trouble of the cow: because often it happens to cows, and there is one only, which is born between the skin and the flesh.
Et uadit in corpore toto, ascendendo et descendendo: et ostenditur sensui apud ambulationem eius de membro ad membrum, donec disrumpit ubicumque disrumpit in cute locum, et egreditur.	And it was seen in the whole body, ascending and descending: and it was shown by sense during its walking with its limb from one limb to another, until it stops wherever it stops in the skin, and a branch goes out.
Et generatio eius est ex putredine quorundam humorum.	And its generation is from the corruption of some earth.
Sicut accidunt uermes et serpentes, id est, lumbrici, et ascarides in uentre.	As happen worms and snakes, that is, earthworms, and roundworms in the belly.
Et timetur ex malicia eius.	And they are afraid of its evil.
Quia quando ipse uadit in corpore, et eleuatur ad caput, et peruenit ad locum: tunc fortasse aperit in eo, et egreditur, et destruit oculum: et accidit illud multotiens.	Because when it goes up in the body and ascends to the head, and reaches a place: then perhaps it opens within, and goes out, and destroys an eye: and this happens often.
Cum ergo uis curare eum, et extrahere ipsum, tunc non fit illud nisi apud ambulationem eius, et apparitionem ipsius sensui.	But when you are to cure it, and to take it out, then it does not happen to it but during its walking, and the appearance of its sense.
Oportet ergo, ut stringas quod est supra eum, et quod est sub eo cum ligamento constrictione forti.	Therefore let you bind what is above it, and what is below it with strong constriction by a ligature.
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	Then dry up on the top of it, and take it out.
Quod si profundatur in carne, et non inuenis ipsum: tunc pone super locum cauterium cum igne, donec moriatur.	That if it penetrates into the flesh, and not into itself: then put on the place a cautery with fire, until it dies.
Et maius quod timetur, est corruptio eius, qua corrumpit oculum, sicut diximus.	And greater than what is feared, is its corruption, which corrupts an eye, as we have said.
Si autem uides eum iam peruenisse in capite prope oculum, tunc stringe sub eo supercilium strictura bona.	If you see it [the wound] having already reached the head near the eye, then tighten the brow above it with a good constriction.
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	Then dry above it, and remove it.
Et oportet ut utatur infirmus mundificatione sui corporis, cum medicinis soluentibus humores putridos malos.	And it is necessary that the sick one should use self-purification of his body, with medicines that dissolve bad putrid humors.
Et caueat sibi a cibis generantibus putrefactionem.	And he should beware of foods that generate putrefaction.
¶ De sectione super aegritudinem Nakir.	[On sectioning on disease] of Naker.
Caput XCV.	Head 105.
Haec aegritudo nominatur in terra nostra Nakir: et est dolor qui accidit in quibusdam membris: deinde permutatur de membro ad membrum.	This disease is called in our language Naker, and it is a pain that happens in some member; then it passes from one member to another.
Et ego quidem iam uidi ipsum, secundum quod narro tibi.	And I have already seen him, according as I report to you.
Vocatus sum ad mulierem infirmam in quibusdam uillis.	I was called to a sick woman in some wounds.
Et detexit brachium suum, et uidi inflationem paruam in uena funis brachii.	And she held out her arm, and I saw an inflammation in the armpit in the axillary vein.
Et postquam remansi hora una, uidi unam inflationem incedere cum focili, sicut incedit uermis, ascendendo ad humerum eius uelocius quam esse potest: ut sit sicut argentum uiuum, quando currit de loco ad locum.	And after an hour had passed, I saw one inflammation go down with a torch, like the burning of the flesh, ascending at her shoulder faster than it can be: so that it is like flowing silver, when it runs from place to place.
Recessit ergo dolor ex illo loco, et fixus est in humero.	Then the pain departed from that place, and was fixed in her shoulder.
Deinde sedi hora una, et cucurrit in reliquum corpus, donec perueniret in brachium aliud.	Then after an hour it moved, and ran over the rest of the body until it reached another arm.
Deinde narrauit mihi, quia reuoluebatur in toto corpore suo, secundum quod uidi.	Then she reported to me that it was moving all over her whole body, according as I saw it.
Miratus sum ergo de uelocitate permutationis eius de membro ad membrum.	I was therefore amazed at the speed of its movement from one member to another.
Et ego quidem ante illud non uideram hanc aegritudinem oculis meis taliter secundum hunc modum.	And I myself have never seen such a disease with my eyes before, moving in this way.
Verumtamen uidi multos, qui inueniunt dolorem permutari de membro ad membrum: et non uidi ipsum oculis, sicut uidi eum in muliere.	However, I have seen many who have experienced pain from one member to another: and I have never seen it with my eyes, like what I saw in the woman.
Et ego non cogito illud esse, nisi quod est propterea, quod mulier fuit ex illis qui sunt ex uillis sicci corporis detectarum uenarum: hinc ergo apparet sensui illa uentositas permutata.	And I do not think that it was, except that the woman was of those who are found among the wounds of dried-up breasts: hence this sense of windiness is apparent.
Et est necesse, ut non appareant secundum hanc rationem in illis qui sunt deliciosi, et corporibus humidis, occultarum uenarum.	It is necessary that they should not appear according to this reason in those who are delicious and wet bodies, of secret wounds.
Cum ergo uis curationem eius, et sentit patiens illud dolorem: tunc si est apparens tibi oculo, sicut diximus, tunc stringe supra ipsum, et sub ipso uelociter: et seca supra ipsum, donec egrediatur illa uentositas coartata: et cauteriza locum.	But when you are curing it and the patient feels this pain, then if it is visible to you with the eye, as we said, then bind it above it and under it quickly: and dry it above it until it comes out that windiness: and cauterize the place.
Si autem non uides ipsum oculis tuis: tunc cura ipsum cum excussione corporis, et cum eo quod expellit uentositates, et carminat eas cum pillulis foetidis, et pillulis de serapino, et similibus.	But if you do not see the place with your eyes: then cure it with the excretion of the body, and with what it expels windiness, and make them red with foul pills, and pills of serapine, and others.
¶ De extractione Sagittarum.	On the extraction of arrows.
Caput XCVI.	Chapter LVI.
Sagittae diuersificantur secundum species suas, et secundum loca in quibus cadunt ex corpore.	Arrows differ according to their species, and according to the places in which they are lodged in the body.
Earum uero diuersitas est: quoniam ex eis sunt quae habent cuspides magnos, et paruos: et concauae, et surdae.	But there is a great difference between them: for some have large hooks, and some are sharp; and some are conic, and some are flat.
Et ex eis sunt quae habent tres angulos.	And of these there are three angles.
Et ex eis quibus sunt linguae.	And of these there are tongues.
Et ex eis quibus sunt astellae.	And of these there are stars.
Illae uero quae sunt secundum membra in quibus cadunt, est secundum duos modos.	But those that fall into members of the body are of two ways.
Aut enim membra sunt ex membris principalibus concauis, sicut cerebrum, et cor, et epar, et pulmo, et renes, et intestina, et uesica, et eis similia.	For example, the members are conic from the main member, such as the brain, and the heart, and the liver, and the lung, and the kidneys, and the intestines, and the bladder, and similar to them.
Quando ergo cadit in aliquo horum membrorum, et apparent tibi signa mortis, quae ego narro tibi post, tunc oportet ut deuites extractionem illius sagittae ex eis, nam mors consequitur illum in quo est, in pluribus dispositionibus.	But when it falls into any of these members and you see to you signs of death, which I will tell you after, then you should extract the arrow from them, because death follows it in many dispositions.
Et quando non apparent tibi ista signa mala, et sagitta non est absconsa in profunditate membri, tunc extrahe ipsam, et cura uulnus.	But when these bad signs do not appear to you, and the arrow is not hidden deep in the member, then pull it out, and cure the wound.
Ex signis enim cerebri quando cadit in eo sagitta, et penetrat os, et egreditur siphac quod est super cerebrum, est: quoniam accidunt ex illo soda uehemens, et scotomia, et uertigo, et rubedo in oculis, et inflatio, et rubedo linguae, et spasmus, et permixtio intellectus, et uomitus cholerae.	For from the signs of a brain when it falls into it an arrow and penetrates the bone, and emerges from above the brain, there follow these: for they happen from this a bloody fainting, and blindness, and dizziness, and blushing in the eyes, and swelling, and stiffness in the tongue, and spasm, and confusion of thought, and loss of memory.
Et fortasse egreditur sanguis ex naribus, aut auribus.	And perhaps blood will flow from the nose, or ears.
Et fortasse abscinditur sermo, et destruitur uox.	And perhaps a speech will be cut off, and a beast will be destroyed.
Et egreditur ex loco uulneris humiditas alba similis pulti.	And blood will flow from the wound's place, white like gruel.
Et exit ex eo simile aquositati carnis.	And will emerge from it similar to meat water.
Si ergo apparent tibi ista signa, tunc abstine a curatione, et extrahe sagittam si non egreditur.	If then you see these signs, then refrain from cure, and draw out the arrow if not blood has flowed.
Signa autem sagittae quando cadit in corde, sunt: quod ipsa est prope mammillam sinistram: et sentit cum ea quasi ipsa sit fixa in re dura, non in re uacua.	The signs of an arrow that has entered the heart, are: for it is near the left nipple: and it feels as if fixed on a hard thing, not on a soft one.
Et fortasse sagittae est motus similis motui pulsus: et currit ex uulnere sanguis niger.	And perhaps the arrow has a movement similar to a pulse: and black blood flows from the wound.
Et sequitur illud frigus extremitatum, et sudor frigidus, et syncopis.	And follows that cold of extremities, and cold sweat, and fainting.
Scias ergo, quod mors descendit procul dubio.	So know, that death has come by certain means.
Et signum sagittae quando uulnerat pulmonem, est exitus sanguinis spumosi ex uulnere: et uasa quae sequuntur collum, apostematur, et mutatur color infirmi.	And the sign of an arrow that has wounded the lung, is: the flow from the wound of frothy blood: and the veins that follow the neck, run away, and change their color to pale.
Et expirat spiritum magnum, altum: et quaerit attractionem aeris frigidi.	And he breathes out great, deep sighs: and seeks the cold air.
Quod si cadat sagitta in uelamen, quod est in pectore: tunc est prope costas paruas: et fit anhelitus magnus cum dolore uehementi, cum suspirio: et mouentur omnia membra humerorum.	That if the arrow has entered the breast-bone, which is within the chest: then it is near the back ribs: and it becomes a great sighing with painful grumbling, and groaning: and all the shoulder muscles quiver.
Et si cadat sagitta in stomachum, tunc fortasse egreditur ex uulnere ex cibo aliquid indigestum.	And if the arrow has entered into the stomach, then perhaps blood flows from the wound by something indigestible in food.
Et si cadit sagitta in Ventrem, et figitur in eo: egreditur aliquid stercoris ex uulnere, aut zirbum, aut intestinum quod iam disruptum est.	And if the arrow has entered into the belly and is fixed there: then blood flows from the wound by stool, or bile, or gut that has already been broken.
Non est ergo spes in curatione eius, neque in extractione sagittae.	There is therefore no hope for his cure, nor for drawing out the arrow.
Quod si sagitta cadat in Vesicam, et egrediatur urina: et procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, et fortior sit dolor super infirmum: tunc scias, quia est mortale.	That if the arrow has entered into the bladder, and it flows out urine: and proceeds from it something toward the outside, and its pain is stronger on the sick: then know that it is mortal.
Reliqua autem membra, sicut facies, et collum, et guttur, et spatula, et adiutorium, et spondiles dorsi, et furcula, et coxa, et crus, et eis similia ex membris saluantur secundum plures dispositiones: quando non inuenit sagitta arteriam, aut neruum: et non est sagitta uenenosa.	Reliqua autem membra, sicut facies, et collum, et guttur, et spatula, et adiutorium, et spondiles dorsi, et furcula, et coxa, et crus, et eis similia ex membris saluantur secundum plures dispositiones: quando non inuenit sagitta arteriam, aut neruum: et non est sagitta uenenosa.
Et ego narro tibi quod uidi de esse harum sagittarum, ut significes per illud super curationem tuam.	And I tell you that I saw such arrows exist, as you mean by that arrow on your cure.
Quod est, quia cuidam uiro cecidit sagitta in lachrymali oculi eius, in radice nasi.	That is, because a man fell an arrow in his lacrimal eye, at the root of his nose.
Extraxi ergo eam ipsi ex parte altera, sub adipe auris eius: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei in oculo eius nocumentum.	I therefore took it out from him on the other side, under the adipose of his ear: and he was healed, and nothing happened to him in his eye.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam Iudaeo, quae cecidit ei in adipe oculi sui sub palpebra inferiori: et sagitta iam occultata erat, et non consecutus sum ex ea nisi extremitatem paruam eius, cum qua adhaeret in ligno suo: et erat sagitta magna ex sagittis arcuum Turcorum, cum ferro leni, in qua non sunt aures.	And I pulled out another arrow from the Jew, which had fallen in his adipose of his eye under his lower eyelid: and the arrow was now hidden, and I could not get at it except by its sharp end, when it was sticking in its wood: and it was an arrow of a Turkish bow, with a soft iron point, and there were no feathers.
Sanatus est ergo Iudaeus, et non accidit in oculo eius accidens malum.	So the Jew was healed, and nothing happened to his eye.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam ex gutture Christiani.	And I pulled out another arrow from the throat of a Christian.
Et erat sagitta arabica, et est illa cui sunt aures.	And it was an Arab arrow, and that one had ears.
Secui ergo super ipsam inter duas guidegi: et iam submersa erat in gutture eius.	So I followed it with two pins: and now it was submerged in his throat.
Subtiliatus sum ergo cum ea, donec extraxi eam: et sanatus est Christianus.	So I was careful with it, until I pulled it out: and the Christian was healed.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam uiro quae ceciderat in uentre eius: et cogitauimus, quia moreretur ex ea.	And I pulled out another arrow that had fallen in his abdomen: and we thought, that he would die of it.
Postquam ergo praeterierunt ei triginta dies, et non mutatum est super eum aliquid ex dispositionibus eius, secui super sagittam: et ingeniaui super eam, et extraxi eam: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei accidens malum.	So then after he had passed forty days, and nothing was changed in him of his sickness, I followed the arrow: and I devised to myself concerning it, and pulled it out: and he was healed, and nothing happened to him.
Et uidi uirum cui cecidit sagitta in dorso eius, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam.	And I saw a man on whom an arrow had fallen in his back, and the wound was healed over it.
Postquam ergo fuit post septem annos, exiuit sagitta in radice coxae eius.	After seven years, he drew the arrow from the root of his hip.
Et uidi mulierem cui cecidit in uentre suo sagitta, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam, et remansit sagitta intra ipsam: et non mutata est ex dispositionibus eius aliqua, et mulier non inuenit ei nocumentum in aliqua ex operationibus suis naturalibus.	And I saw a woman to whom an arrow had fallen into her belly, and a bone was set upon her, and the arrow remained within her: and there was no change in any of her members, and she found no harm in any of her natural operations.
Et uidi uirum alium, cui cecidit sagitta in facie sua: et consolidatum est uulnus, et remansit, non inueniens ei multum dolorem: et similia istis multa.	And I saw another man to whom an arrow had fallen into his face, and a bone was set upon him, and the arrow remained, not causing him much pain: and there were many similar cases.
Et extraxi sagittam uiro ex principibus Regis, quae ceciderat ei in medio nasi sui, et iam declinauerat ad partem dextram parumper: et occultata erat sagitta tota.	And I drew out the arrow from the prince of the king, which had fallen into his nose and had already turned towards the right side somewhat: and the arrow was entirely concealed.
Vocatus sum ergo ad curationem eius post casum sagittae usque ad tres dies.	So they called me to cure him after the loss of the arrow for three days.
Inueni ergo uulnus sagittae strictum ualde.	And I found the arrow-bone very stiff.
Inquisiui ergo eam cum tenta subtili, et non sensi eam: et ipse quidem inueniebat punctionem et dolorem sub aure sua ex parte dextra.	So I examined it with a delicate attempt, and I did not feel it: and he himself felt a prick and pain under his right ear.
Speraui ergo, quod erat illa punctio ex extremitate sagittae.	So I hoped that it was from the end of the arrow.
Emplastraui ergo locum cum emplastro in quo erat uirtus attractiua, et digestiua, confidens apud me, quod apostemaretur locus, et appareret mihi signum sagittae, ut secarem super eam: et non accidit in loco accidens significans quod sagitta consecuta sit locum.	So I plastered the place where there was the attracting and curative force of the arrow, confiding to him that it would heal, so that the mark of the arrow might appear to me as if it were being taken off: and no accident happened in that place suggesting that the arrow was still there.
Assiduaui ergo cum emplastro super eum diebus multis: et non accidit accidens, et consolidatum est uulnus interim: et remansit infirmus de extractione eius spacio dierum, donec sensit sagittam die quodam intra nasum suum.	So I kept up the plaster for many days: and no accident happened, and the bone was set during that time: and he remained weak from the drawing out of it for a space of days, until one day he felt an arrow in his nose.
Et narrauit mihi illud.	And he told me about that.
Posui ergo super illud uulnus medicinam acutam, corrosiuam diebus multis, donec apertum est: et cum tenta tentaui ipsum, et sensi extremitatem sagittae subtilem quae adhaeret in ligno.	So I put an acute medicine on that bone, for many days, until it was healed over: and when I tried him, I felt a slight pain of the arrow still attached to the bone.
Deinde addidi in apertione uulneris per illam medicinam acutam, donec apparuit nobis uisibiliter extremitas sagittae: et praeteriit mihi cum eo spacium temporis circiter quatuor menses.	Then, when the wound had healed over by means of that acute medicine, it seemed to me that the tip of the arrow became visible; and about four months elapsed with that time.
Deinde postquam amplificatum est uulnus, et possible fuit mihi intromittere forcipes in ipsam, et mouere ipsam, et non obediuit ad exitum: tunc non cessaui subtiliare, et ingeniare super eam cum modis ingeniorum, donec coepi super eam die quodam cum forcipibus decenter factis, secundum quod ueniet forma eorum in fine capituli, donec extraxi eam.	Then, when the wound had increased and seemed to me that it was possible for me to insert my fingers into it and move them and not respond to exit: then I did not stop gently, and devised means for her with the means of inventiveness, until one day I succeeded in doing so with a certain angle of unevenly made forks, according to which their form became visible at the end of the chapter, and I removed it.
Deinde restauraui uulnus.	Then I restored the limb.
Et medici quidem iudicant, quod cartilago nasi non restauratur.	And the doctors say that cartilage is not restored.
Restauraui ergo ipsam, et consolidatum est uulnus, et sanatus est infirmas sanitate integra: nec nocuit ei aliquid omnino.	So I restored it, and the limb was consolidated, and the disease was healed with complete health: and he did not hurt at all.
Et ego narro tibi qualitatem extractionis quarundam sagittarum: ut ponas illud regulam et significationem super illud quod non dixi.	And I tell you the quality of extraction of certain arrows: that you set up that rule and meaning about it which I did not say.
Quoniam partes huius artis et distinctiones earum non comprehenduntur cum narratione: neque comprehendit illud liber, et artifex prudens comparat cum pauco super multum: et cum eo quod est paesens, super illud quod est absens: et inuenit operationem nouam, et instrumentum nouum apud descensus rerum extranearum huius artis quando accidunt.	For parts of this art and their distinctions do not understand themselves with a narration; nor does this book understand, and the careful artisan compares little to much: and when it is far from what is present, he understands a new operation, and a new instrument when extraneous things of this art happen.
Dico ergo, quod sagittae non egrediuntur ex membris quibus sunt fixae, nisi secundum duos modos.	I say, that arrows do not come out of the body from which they are fixed except according to two ways.
Aut per attractionem ex loco ex quo intrauit.	Or by attraction from a place from which it entered.
Aut contrario partis alterius.	Or by the opposite side of another part.
Et illa quae egreditur unde intrauit, aut est sagitta procedens in loco carnoso: et attrahitur, et egreditur.	And that which goes out from where it entered, or is an arrow proceeding in a fleshly place; and is attracted, and goes out.
Quod si non obedit ad exitum ex hora in qua cadit: tunc oportet ut dimittas ipsam aliquot diebus, donec putrefiat caro quae est in circumitu eius: et alleuietur attractio eius, et eius egressio.	That if it does not obey to exit within the time in which it falls: then it is necessary that you leave it a few days, until it rotten the flesh which is around it: and its attraction is eased, and its exit.
Et similiter si figitur in osse, et non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc dimitte ipsam etiam aliquot diebus: et itera eam cum attractione et motione omni die, donec egreditur.	And likewise if it is fixed in a bone, and does not obey to you to exit, then leave it too for a few days: and again go out with its attraction and movement every day, until it goes out.
Quod si non obedit tibi ad exitum post dies, tunc oportet ut perfores in circumitu sagittae in ipso osse ab omni parte cum terebro subtili, donec amplificentur sagittae.	If he does not obey you at the exit after a few days, then it is necessary that you perform on him around the sagitta in the bone from all parts with thin terrae, until the sagitta are increased.
Deinde attrahe eam, et extrahe ipsam.	Then attract it and take it out.
Si autem sagitta est fixa in capitis osse, et iam processit in uno uentrium cerebri, et apparent ex infirmo quaedam illorum accidentium quae dixi: tunc abstine ab attractione sagittae, et dimitte eam, donec aequetur esse eius post dies.	If however the sagitta is fixed in the osse capitis, and has already gone into one of the ventrums cerebri, and appears from an accident which I have mentioned: then abstain from attracting the sagitta, and let it go, until it is even with that after a few days.
Nam si sagitta peruenit ad sifach, tunc mors non prolongatur ei.	For if the sagitta goes into the Sifach (a part of the brain), then death does not prolong itself for him.
Et si sagitta non est fixa, nisi in corpore ossis tantum, et non penetrat usque ad sifach: et remanet infirmus aliquot diebus, et non accidit ei ex illis accidentibus aliquid: tunc ingenia in attractione sagittae et extractione eius.	And if the sagitta is not fixed, but only in the body of the bone, and does not penetrate all the way to the Sifach: and remains a few days sick, and does not happen to him any of those accidents which I mentioned: then devise in attracting the sagitta and taking it out.
Si autem est fixa ualde, et non obedit tibi ad attractionem: tunc administra terebella in circumitu sagittae, sicut narraui tibl: deinde cura locum, donec sanetur.	If however it is firmly fixed, and does not obey you with regards to attracting it: then apply thin terrae around the sagitta, as I have told you: and then take care of the place, until it heals.
Si autem Sagitta iam absconsa est in loco corporis, et occultatur et absconditur a sensu: tunc inquire eam cum tenta.	If however the sagitta has already gone into hiding in a place in the body, and is hidden and concealed from sensation: then seek it out with care.
Si autem sentis eam, tunc attrahe eam cum quibusdam instrumentis quae conueniunt attractioni eius.	If you feel it, then attract it with some instruments which are suitable for attracting it.
Si autem non potes super eam, propter constrictionem uulneris, et propter longitudinem sagittae in profundo: et non est illic os, neque neruus, neque uena: tunc finde super eam, donec amplificetur uulnus, et sit possibile extrahere sagittam.	If you cannot bring it out because of the constriction of the wound, and because of the length of the sagitta in the deep, and there is no bone, nor nerve, nor vessel: then find it out, until the wound is increased, and it is possible to take out the sagitta.
Quod si sunt ei aures quibus teneatur, tunc libera carnem fixam in eis ab omni parte, omni ingenio quo potes illud, et ingenia, si non potest super euasionem carnis in fractura aurium, et contorsione earum, donec euadat.	That if they have ears to which it is attached, then free the flesh firmly held on them from all parts, with any device which you can: and devise, if it cannot be brought out by means of the ears in a fracture, and turning of them, until it comes away.
Et tu quando administras extractionem Sagittae, in quocumque loco est, tunc utere contorsione manus tuae, cum forficibus ad partes omnes, donec facias eam euadere: et subtilia ultima subtilitate, ut non frangatur Sagita, et fiat difficilis tibi attractio eius, et ipsius extractio.	And when you are extracting the arrow of the shaft, in whatever place it is, then use your hand with forceps to all parts until you make it bleed: and the subtlest subtlety, so that the shaft does not break, and it becomes difficult for you to attract it, and its extraction.
Quod si non potes super eam ex hora una, tunc dimitte eam diebus aliquot, donec putrefiant quae sunt in circumitu eius.	That if you cannot get above it in one hour, then let go of it for a few days, until what is around it putrefies.
Deinde itera eam: alleuietur enim tuncia Si uero contrarietatem tibi facit fluxus sanguinis, tunc administra quod diximus ex curatione in capitulo suo: et custodi uirtutem tuam ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, aut chordae.	Then repeat it: for indeed if the flow of blood annoys you, then administer what we have said in its chapter: and guard your skill from the incision of the vein, or nerve, or chordae.
Et administra ingenium omni modo quo tibi possibile est euasionis Sagittae: et sit illud cum facilitate, et tranquillitate, uel tarditate, et firmitate, sicut narraui tibi.	And administer skill in every way as possible to the healing of the arrow: and let it be with ease, and tranquillity, or tardiness, and firmness, as I tell you.
Et oportet, ut facias cum trahis Sagittam, ut infirmus sit secundum figuram, secundum quam fuit apud casum Sagittae in ipso.	And it is necessary that when you draw out the arrow, you make it so that it is weakened according to the figure, according to which it was with the shaft at the site of the arrow.
Quoniam est magis iuuatiuum.	For it is more sure.
Si autem non est tibi possibile illud, tunc administra quod tibi est possibile ex figuris.	But if this is not possible for you, then administer what is possible for you from figures.
Sagitta autem quae egreditur ex contrario partis alterius, aut iam procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora: aut facit gibbositatem extremitas Sagittae per sensum ex superiore parte cutis propinquae, et uides eam eminentem: seca ergo super eam, et sit sectio secundum quantitatem quod capiant in ea forcipes.
